summary: Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
14 silver and bronze coins of unknown denominations: Republic - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 145-176).
64 denarii found in a wall of a glass workshop: Nerva - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
A large hoard of 1,500-2,000 coins: 508 republican coins are identified; all the emperors up to Hadrian are represented except Augustus.
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 25 coins were seen: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoards with Strunga I and III.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a stone. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the antonine dynasty.

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 57.89 g.
The hoard comprised 24 bronze coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
Around 100 denarii, among them, one of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.
Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
4 asses found during excavations: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45373-45376

summary: 54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questioned whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Two or four coins are missing.
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the two Faustinae (AD 138-180).
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
(21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: Two groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinstone Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as one find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 113-114 with four intruding coins.
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: 16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD
A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
Two aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).
15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: Around 500 denarii. Only three are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (1 Antoninus Pius), Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous Commodus), found in grave 4 in Sevasti.

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.
52 denarii of Hadrian of only three RIC types: RIC 119, 256, 339 (AD 134-138). Found together with some bits of amber.

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).
The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).

A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: A hoard of about 500 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by a treasure hunter somewhere near the Dniester, on the borderland of the Ternopil and Ivano-Frankivsk region. The hoard was found in a pot (a few fragments are preserved). Several coins were glued to the fragments of the vessel. The coins are quite well preserved (minimal wear). Deposit was not published on Violity, and was immediately sold to one of the collectors. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.
(ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: 1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagstones at the south-eastern end of the basilica.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 14 denarii found with metal detectoring. Galba to Antoninus Pius.
157 coins found in a ceramic vessel: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

Six silver coins minted in Caesarea of Cappadocia: Nerva, Trajan 2, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius. According to Pachomov they are coming from a destroyed burial ground. a plausible hypothesis as Kropotkin (2005) mentioned other similar coins found in graves (p. 267; nos. 1927, 1928, 1944).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 84974)

summary: The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.

3rd century. "Six coins, a small mid-3rd century AD hoard, found in soil (751A), 3 sealed by east wall (763) of Structure Y [a trapezoidal stone-walled enclosure appended to inner wall face of the round]. Another coin found in (728), the surface of Structure Y, & 2 more in overlying soil (785). These 3 coins of similar date & condition, & formed part of scattered hoard.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, Sixpenny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: Two denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
8 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as, 1 AE: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of coins found during construction work. Only five denarii are known: Republic, Vitellius, Antoninus Pius (2), Lucius Verus.
disposition: Before World War II some of the coins from the hoard were kept in the collections of the St. Elisabeth Gymnasium in Wrocław (Sankt Elisabet- Gymnasium in Breslau). Lost

summary: Hoard of 759 bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). Uncertain whether is part of MORSHANSKOYE 1838 hoard (?) or a separate one.
Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with two silver vessels embedded each other.
270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).

151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.
50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: 79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
(ca. 900) 889 denarii: 46 republican, 843 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Found in two vessels.
disposition: Regional Museum of Russe, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1618 (889 coins)

summary: Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: 3,561 coins of Lucius Verus.
9 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
Hoard of 31 denarii. Only one denarius of Antoninus Pius is known.
Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: 20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: 86 denarii: Mark-Antony - Commodus (Crispina) (AD 180-191).
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: 5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).
Hoard of around 50 denarii. 21 coins were brought for examination by the finder: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1,750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.

A clump of at least 14 denarii molten together. The only reasonably identifiable coin is one of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I, minted between 141 and 161 AD. Another denarius was likely issued under the authority of Marcus Aurelius.

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.

In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limestone tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered two golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were two ceramic vessels buried at 2 m one from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).

A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.
Two medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were seven bronze tintinnabula, one patera, and two iron objects.
The hoard was discovered in 2013 within the boundaries of Vaukavyski County. Consisted of at least 140 denarii (Nerva-Commodus). The circumstances and exact location of the find are unknown.
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.

The hoard comprised 7 aurei terminating in an issue of Trajan dating to AD 106. From 1826 to 1908, 7 Roman aurei were found by chance in the fields, all in the same region (Salzbrunnen and Z'underst Wyler), at a maximum distance of ca. 150 meters. These could be single finds or rather a dispersed hoard? Found in 1826: Nerva; 1859: Nero; 1894: Vespasian; 1896: Trajan; 1899: Nerva; 1907: Galba; 1908: Trajan.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Schaffhausen (4 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (2 coins); Bernisches Historisches Museum (1 coin)

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: 15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
A roll of eight corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
The hoard was discovered near the village in 2011. Consisted of 13 denarii (Trajan-Pertinax). The circumstances of the find and the place of the coins storage are unknown.
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
13 denarii found with a money-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins, dating between AD 79/80 and AD 119/120.

Eleven coins found over three private searches; one in 2009, four in 2011 and six in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.
86 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156).
2 denarii of Hadrian
5 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 14.16 g.
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: 865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: A hoard of 310 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) and their barbarian imitations was discovered by treasure hunters in November 2017 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and the first 104 coins were published on November 29, 2017, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity, followed by the next 117 coins on December 6, 2017. The hoard was discovered by four treasure hunters in a ploughed field and appears to have been partially ploughed (the coins were collected from a relatively large area). A total of 310 coins were found, which were divided among the finders (two of the treasure hunters did not publish photos of their coins). The coins were in a hand-made vessel, a significant part of which has been preserved. A silver buckle, a bronze brooch, an iron knife with a bone handle and a “spinning wheel-like thing” (probably a knife tip?) were also found with the coins (all artefacts are specific for the Chernyakhiv culture). The coins are very poorly preserved (heavily worn). One of the coins was pierced, another had a plugged hole. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
1,300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".
In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: 50 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177-178). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 1, practically, one hoard.
The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. One coin bears the effigy of Faustina II
7 coins found at 30 cm deep: 2 sestertii, 5 asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
Some silver coins found in a garden. Only one denarius of Hadrian and one of Commodus were documented.

The hoard (4 coins, Republic - Faustina I/II) was found with around 20 coins in 1772 during the digging of a draw well in front of the castle. - not sure which castle is meant, as there are three of them in Jagsthausen.
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: 368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).

15 Roman gold coins described in the Madras Museum Accessions Register as 'purchases through individuals through the Collector of Canara'. It is unclear whether rhey represent a genuine hoard. Possible part of the cache of Roman coins dating from the first and second centuries A.D. was reportedly discovered some 600 kms. further to the north, on Kadmat Island in the neighbouring Laccadives group (Indian Union Territory of Lakshadweep) during 1948
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: 33 bronze coins found together in one insula of the former Roman city of Baetulo.
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: 12 coins listed as 'loosely associated with the hoard' from Cadeby in CHRB (no. 2519) and said to have been found 60-80 yards away. These were treated as a separate Treasure Trove case so an additional entry has been created here. They may have been part of another scattered hoard.
Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).
Unknown original number of coins. 225 coins were known: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
Four coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!
Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.

Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely one owner.
300 denarii, found with a ceramic vessel 237 coins were recovered: Otho – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (227 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (10 coins; inv.no. 361)

summary: Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.
7 denarii, ending with Marcus Aurelius AD 176. No further information.

The hoard was found in a heap of stones without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of stones with no obvious container.
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: 1,776 denarii (5.5 kg): Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Most likely were kept in a wooden box, as eight silver rivets "have been discovered at the site".

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: 15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only three coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: 513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: 2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.
A hoard of 257 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176).
disposition: Museum, Dortmund (243 coins); the Ruhr Valley Museum in Schwerte and Fröndenberg (14 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: 300 denarii: Augustus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of coins. Six denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.
Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: 17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).
Around 1,460 denarii - a number established based on an average weight of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: 100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
9 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
100 coins of which one bronze coin of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
disposition: Private collection and museum Eindhoven, Netherlands

summary: 18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).
The hoard comprised 9 aurei from Antoninus Pius to Marcus Aurelius.
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Weight: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 7 sestertiiare known: Trajan - Commodus (AD 181).
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.
15 AE to AD 195.

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: 110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: 7 coins found stuck together: 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 as: Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 121-122).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 315/90)

summary: The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), two unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".

Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only one was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which sixteen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
12 bronze coins found stuck together, in a barrow: 5 dupondii, 7 asses: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: National History and Archaeology Museum, Constanța, Romania (inv.nos. 81602-81613)

summary: This hoard was found in three ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.

IARCH record for a hoard of 30 denarii found between 1985 and 1992. The latest coins are two of Lucius Verus and Divus Antoninus both dated to AD 161 and an undated coin of Faustina II. This might suggest deposition in the earlier part of the reign of Marcus Aurelius. See WMID-1AC648 for full details and images. One of the coins of Trajan is a small fragment.

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The hoard comprised 10 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. TAF interprets the hoard as being a purse drop.
At least 4 denarii found on a field: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I).
The hoard comprised 16 coins with the denominations not given. The hoard was found on the Barre farm, while making repairs to the farmyard.

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: Hoard of 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Two denarii are documented: Faustina II, Commodus.
Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.

Initially, circa 2,050 coins. Only 1,938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
The hoard comprised 53 sestertii terminating in issues of Antoninus Pius and 'the young Marcus Aurelius'.
322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.
Originally, 78 denarii, 14 preserved: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 189); silver weight: 36.63 g. (14 coins).
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).

Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: This hoard was found in a Roman building. It consisted of 7 denarii, ranging from the late Republic to Antoninus Pius. The coins lay stratified in a roll and the find appears to be complete.
A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).
27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

Three denarii (1 of Trajan and 2 of Septimius Severus that share the same obverse die) from the same context (C/26/34), that may represent a small hoard, found at Kifrin, a large fortified settlement with Parthian and Roman phases of the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, on the east bank of the Euphrates.
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only one bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).
Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Łódź, Poland (2 coins)

summary: Large hoard of Roman denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.

5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. One interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.
(c. 400) 3 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: Archaeological Museum Charleroi, Belgium 13 coins, only 5 retrieved)

summary: 21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.

Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
40 bronze coins were discovered with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 have provided some information: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).
120 denarii. 32 were donated to the History Museum in Silistra: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).
2,250 denarii: Galba – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
(?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
135 denarii found by metal detecting: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). Together were found: Flint pendant; an iron chain; a ceramic spindle.
Seven aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.

2 denarii: Titus, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II); silver weight: 4.80 g. Together were found: loop of gold bracteate, 2 gold bands, 3 bronze pins, bronze sword (in miniature), 1 small bronze ring, various bronze fragments.
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.
Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.
Group of 15 first and second century copper alloy coins metal-detected from the same field over a period of years between 1990 and 1998.

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.
15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: 236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).

12 denarii, of which 10 plated, were found with a ceramic vessel in a garbage pit: Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 3, Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) 2, Marcus Aurelius 1, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1 (post AD 173-174).

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 22 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 139)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest

summary: Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 270.19 g. (100 coins).
A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)
5-6 silver and bronze coins. Among them one piece of Antoninus Pius.
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
Two denarii of Commodus (AD 186); silver weight: 4.66 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.

The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.
10 coins. Unknown denominations: Augustus - Hadrianus (AD 117-138).
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: A large hoard of denarii and a few bronze coins was found during construction works in 1957. Only 139 coins (Vespasian-Marcus Aurelius, 70-180 AD) were recovered but subsequently stolen in 1972-1973.
Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are mentioned), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether three antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.
6 sestertii recorded with the PAS, 3 further from excavation of the site (see Amber Valley barbarous radiate hoard). Not classed as Treasure.
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
130 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 360.44 g. Together with the coins were found two bronze rings.

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
Heap of sestertii, 6: Trajan 4, Commodus 1, uncertain 1 (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: A find, comprising one aureus and seven denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Antonine period.
4 coins: 1 denarius, 3 sestertii: Vespasian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (2)
Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
(c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: Hoard of 11 denarii.
45 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 106.55 g. (41 coins)
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 6293); Gotlands Fornsal, Visby, Finland A 1922 (inv.nos. A 2090, A 2091)

summary: Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)
A potful of Roman silver coins. Only five coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.
35 denarii found among stones: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only two coins are preserved
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian

A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
30 denarii: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). Found near the Roman villa.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 10 pieces are known: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-192).
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.
Hoard of 47 Roman aurei documented in the archives of the Real Academia de la Historia - Antonio Delgado Fund: Nero - Antoninus Pius for Faustina II (AD 145-161).
10 bronze coins found during archaeological excavations: 5 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 3 asses: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: History Museum, Svištov, Bulgaria; inv.nos OF 3583-3588; HCF, inv.no. 886-889

summary: 101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).

The details of the hoard are not well known. Found in 1871 it passed possession multiple times and was eventually split. Originally 387 silver coins were found, and one gold piece, along with several urns. Only 12 pieces are described: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla Augusta).
3 denarii: Titus, Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 148-149); silver weight: 7.90 g.
645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
The hoard comprises a small greyware vessel containing 12 denarii of one of the Faustinas.
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
Grave find of 5 denarii (1 plated) Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 134-138)
Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).

The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: 2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver weight: 5.06 g.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: (8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).

A hoard of denarii was found approx. 0.7 km northwest of Ausleben, on the Ausleber Hoch (alt. 135 m) in a probable neolithic grave mound. 142 coins (Otho-Commodus) were described, but the total amount of coins is unknown.
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: 68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: 1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: 300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).

A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"
38 bronze coins: 2 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 28 asse, 4 dupondii or asses: Titus - Commodus (AD 192).
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)

81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
