Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: Hoard of 282 coins: 252 denarii, 1 quinarius, 29 bronzes: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Hoard of 200 bronze coins: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.
Hoard of 23 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 52.27 g.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: 160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
Hoard of circa 600-700 denarii. 433 pieces were studied: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.

After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.
c. 20 denarii: Vitellius - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (6 coins); Private collection (21 coins)

summary: More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: The hoard comprised 218 Syrian tetradrachms from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian.
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'
Unknown originally number of coins. 68 denarii are kept in the collection of the Library of the Romanian Academy: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 29069-29136)

summary: Three denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
Hoard of circa 700 denarii. Only 350 pieces are known: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Antonine dynasty. Only four coins are documented.

A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
A find of 45 Roman denarii (Otho - Antoninus Pius) was made in a garden in Vicht. The coins were found in charcoal residues.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.
Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only two of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.
(180) 141 silver coins: 140 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm dating from the Republic to Trajan.
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (141 coins)

summary: 38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of five coins, three of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, one cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
The hoard comprised 831 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
Few dozens of denarii of the Antonine dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 295 denarii and 2 sestertii (Mark Antony to Commodus) found on the latest floor level of Room 37. The coins were corroded together and no trace of a container was recovered. It is possible that 6 denarii presented to the British Museum in January 1930 by the Caerleon Excavation Committee may have come from this hoard (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Jan. 1930: Vespasian, 1; Hadrian, 3; Antoninus Pius, 1; Commodus, 1).

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
112 bronze coins: 111 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).
The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: 75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: 47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).
Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
Initially were found 81 coins. 44 coins: 1 cistophorus, 1 sestertius, 9 asses, 33 unknown bronze denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Arheoloski Muzej Istre, Pula, Croatia (44 coins); othewise dispersed

summary: Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins and 1 bronze coin dated to the second century AD.

About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.
Seven bronze coins: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153) found secreted in a wall of a vaulted storage room during excavation of a granary.
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: Eighteen Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). Two additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a ten-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.

A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in five ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.

A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are mentioned. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are mentioned; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals intended for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius two or three Faustinas and one Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: The coins were found in 1938/39 during excavation works on the west wall in the region of Geilenkirchen-Linnich (Kreis Jülich). 14 of the coins were lost. The remaining 21 ones are sestertii, ranging from Trajan to Commodus. All are very worn.
9 sestertii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 181).
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: 2500-3000 denarii. 250 pieces were bought by the National Museum in Sofia: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.

Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).

Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
3 coins, of which one aureus of Trajan (AD 114-117).

This hoard of 43 aurei, ranging from Nero to Marcus Aurelius, was discovered in June 2000 during the archaeological excavation at Plantation Place, Fenchurch Street, in the City of London. The coins were discovered in situ within a uniform context of silty brick-earth with organic inclusions. The absence of coins of Commodus suggests a deposition date probably no later than AD 180.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: 25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).
Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly one hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and one of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
6 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II (AD 145-175).

A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh
Purse(?) of four sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian I 2 (AD 121-122) found near a wall in the area of the civil town.

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
40 denarii and 30 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Commodus (Crispina).
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the contents of a purse lost when the building was demolished.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the contents of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: 271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
180 sestertii, for 109 the issuers are known: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt (95 coins); 5 in Prfratbesitz; Museum St. Veit an der Glan (12 coins); 5 private collection, Austria

summary: The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.
31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: "In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
Unknown number of denarii. V. Haralanov studied 52 pieces: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least five pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
Hoard of an unknown number of Roman imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii produced some information: Augustus 1, Nero 2, Hadrian 1, 1 broken.
A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
The hoard comprised 22 aurei (70 ca.-158-159 AD) found most likely between the West Bank, Upper Galilee and the Golan.
Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: 107 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Republic - Trajan (AD 112-114).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Lugo, Spain

summary: 272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: 15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.

A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: 107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 60kg of sestertii mixed with some middle bronzes (2,500-3000 coins). Only 26 sestertii and 1 dupondius were preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 98-117). The hoard was found by a worker, planting a vineyard.
disposition: History Museum, Louresse-Rochemenier, France (10 coins); finder (17 coins)

summary: 826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.

During the excavation of the Antonine Wall fort on the Bar Hill, a hoard of 13 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) was found at the bottom of a well. Most of them were imitations, 10 of them were cast of pure tin. Only two of the coins, of Mark Antony and of Vespasian, were genuine struck denarii of silver. One coin, of Hadrian, seemed to be of some alloy of copper, and the remaining 10 coins were cast, of almost pure tin, with no trace of alloy. Of these tin coins, five, of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds, and three others, also of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds. It has been suggested that these were shams expressly manufactured for devotional purposes (throwing of money into wells from superstitious motives).
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.

According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.
Unknown originally number of coins. 40 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
149 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 147 imperial denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.
(over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.
Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
Six gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
NA
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).
Originally 66 denarii, 55 preserved: Titus - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 155.21 g.
(14) 10 coins of unknown denomination: Celtic, Republic, Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
215 denarii: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: 70 imperial bronze coins of poor state of conservation. Among them, issues of Antoninus Pius 12, Faustina I 1.
(200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
In 1934, 40 denarii and 12 sestertii were found with an urn in a field north of Narcott Lane. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
(200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest six coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1,300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1,660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: 14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.
Five 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
Three denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: 11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.
Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
48 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) (AD 138-161).
disposition: History and Art Museum, Bacău, Romania

summary: Funerary deposit of 5 denarii in a Late Roman grave: Trajan - Commodus (AD 192). In the same grave were found: a bronze brooch, an iron brooch, an iron bracket, one thorn, an iron firesteel and two knives.
378 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
The hoard comprised 31 tetradrachms, 17 denarii, and 7 bronze coins from the Bar Kohba Revolt (AD 132-136) and one denarius of Trajan.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).
29 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

summary: 28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).

disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

summary: 40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).

A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
Three aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.
19 asses found within one square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in four ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
3760 silver coins, only 10 are available for study: Vitellius - Commodus (AD 180)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania (10 coins in 1914); otherwise, dispersed.

summary: Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.
Initially, there were 1,500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found one gold and two silver ingots.
109 coins: 105 bronze coins, 4 silver denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163). Also part of the deposit were the head of a hair pin and a ring. Considered as a votive offering.
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .

A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains seven of the 217 denarii.
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.
Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.
7 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in a building from the military vicus.

summary: 126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.

summary: Four 2nd c. AD coins were found during sharding in Flurdistrikt above the Geybach river.

The hoard comprised 13 denarii from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus. They were found concealed in the belt of male burial interpreted as being that of a Roman soldier. The burial was found in the courtyard of a building situated at No. 12 rue des Fantasques
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla) (AD 193).

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millstone by workmen removing "a quantity of loose stones and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only one lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania: Vespasian – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 2042-2059).

summary: The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: 105 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
2830 silver coins: 2827 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 2 drachms: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 196-197); silver weight: before restoration: 9,290g; after restoration: 9,075.17g
disposition: History Museum ”Iulian Antonescu” Bacau, Bacau County, Romania

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
A hoard of 5 denarii (Vitellius - Lucilla), found while digging peat not far from Nauen. A connection with the hoard of BUCHOW-KARPZOW (ID 17335) has been postulated.
7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).
Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).

Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (one Arabian drachm; three drachms of Cyrenaica and one hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which two imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of one massive silver buckle for a sword belt and two buckles for a girdle. The find also contains eighty-four silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: 13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.
116 coins - 3 aurei and 113 denarii - found together during the archaeological excavations
Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)

The hoard of 79 denarii (one Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and one Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.

summary: The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: The hoard was found in a grave in the Gallo-Roman cemetery. A red ceramic urn was discovered, alongside a small bronze box containing a gold finger ring with glass setting and three aurei of Nero, Domitian and Antoninus Pius. It is not altogether clear whether the coins were found in the box or the urn.
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.
Four coins of Bar Kochba (AD 132-136).
(c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: c. 367.1-588.9 g.
The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of stones and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.

The hoard comprised 4 coins including one earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and two Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: Three denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: 102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.
Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.

Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: Hoard of 104 denarii (317.79g): Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). There is no information on the no. of coins per issuer.

Two denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. One might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
Hoard of circa 86-87 aurei found with a ceramic vessel with a graffiti "IRENE": Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.
2 denarii: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164); silver weight: 5.33 g.
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
110 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Dispersed.
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins: 999 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: Poltava Local History Museum (954 specimens; inv.nos. 4919-4920, 5090)

summary: The hoard comprised 'approximately 60 sestertii, mostly illegible. 10 identifiable examples were of Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II), Commodus and perhaps, Didius Julianus' Archives of Musée de Rouen. Communication by Mme. Aubin (28.11.1982)
40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel, which was recovered in fragments and comprised 228 denarii. Part of the hoard (estimated at 58 coins) was sold but the landowner kept 200 or 201 denarii from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.

Four bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only seven of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
220 denarii: Republican (163), Imperial (57); Republican - Antoninus Pius (AD post 141)
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (49 coins)

summary: (8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii mentioned that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. One denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).
7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: 22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
55 billon drachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-155) found at floor level in a room during excavations of a house.
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 78.0-122.8 g.
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (22 coins); National History Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.no. 92088; 105 coins); private collection (1 coin)

summary: 175 denarii: Republic – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'
36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.
(c. 600) 300 silver coins: 299 denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.
23 coins (2 denarii; 21 provincial coins: Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedonia) found in grave 12 in Sevasti.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 sestertii of the Antonine period.
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).
IARCH record for a hoard of 14 denarii. For further details and images see WMID-01F18E. Unpublished catalogue by Richard Abdy.

c. 1400 coins, mostly aurei, of which only 45 specimens were recorded, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius (43 aurei, 1 denarius of Nero and 1 of Galba), found during illegal excavations in Kuşakkaya.
disposition: Adıyaman museum; Kahramanmaraş museum; private collection in Ankara

summary: 52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

14 coins (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius, mostly bronzes) were found embedded in fire debris, on terrain M, Handwerkerbau (Fläche 60, Planum 0-1). N.B. Coin 1 (Vespasian) is wrongly described as a denarius in FMRD.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
Four Roman bronze coins, excavated in shell sand north of the island Süderoog. The find depth was approximately 6 m.

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average weight of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).

A hoard of 5+ Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica: 1; Amphipolis: 4, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus), found in a grave in Amphipolis (Grave 1) in 1953. Archives in the Ephorate mention 18 further coins, but these could not be traced any more.
Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius
92 silver coins, 90 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175); weight: 292.04 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra Neamț, Romania (inv.nos. 28530-

summary: A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with three silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The content of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.

274 coins: 75 sestertii, 117 dupondii, 74 asses, 7 dupondii/asses, 1 bronze medallion: Gaius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-176). Together with the coins were found: 2 silver pans, 1 silver plate, silver wire bracelet.
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)
556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.
The hoard was discovered after 1863 in the rubble from the excavation of the bathhouse. It comprises 21 aurei, ranging from Nero to Trajan.
17 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 186-187)
disposition: Collection L. Eloy, Namur, Belgium (14 coins), in 1966

summary: The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.

Over 4,500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.
Unknown initial number of coins. 82 bronze coins were studied: 81 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Titus - Gordian III (AD 240/241).
