290 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLV

summary: 40 sestertii discovered at 1.40 m depth. Among them 2 of Commodus and 7 or 8 of Postumus (AD 260-268?). No further information.
The hoard comprised a whiteware jug containing between 800 and 900 coins (or 2,000 according to De Closmadeuc): Philip I - Tacitus (Ad 275-276).
disposition: Musée départemental d'archéologie , Nantes, France (900 coins and sherds from the vessel)

summary: 4 coins: 1 denarius, 2 plated coins, 1 bronze coin: Tiberius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 6.1-7.4 g. Found together with silver inscribed objects (patera, 2 rings), 2 statuettes, 3 hair-pins.
disposition: Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 815 silver coins found with a metal bucket: Julia Domna to Philip I; silver weight: 1019.3-2117.9g
disposition: National History of Antiquities Bucharest, Romania (815 coins) - 1886

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 4,000 plated coins. The hoard was found by workmen digging ditches on the ancient route from Mans to Paris.
The hoard comprised close to 1,800 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Postumus.
Circa 700 antoniniani (radiates), 371 recovered; silver weight: c.190.0-874.0 g.
The hoard comprised an 'unknown number of sestertii and 12 silver coins of Gordian III': Nerva - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.
127 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Carus (AD 282-283) found on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 102 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel in a layer of fire. 28 denarii survived: Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Gordian III (AD 241-243; silver weight: 44.4-85.4 g.
The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.
Within an ancient settlement was found a deposit of iron tools. Beneath were discovered 280 silver and bronze coins. The latest one from the mid-3rd century AD. No further information.
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel including Roman coins. The hoard was dispersed immediately. The hoard was found during house construction on the site of the church of the Jacobins: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
152 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217). Circumstances of find not known.
30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 39.0-70.0 g.

The hoard was found in the south-eastern corner of Ulpia Traiana, south of the city walls and close to the Roman port. It comprised 46 sestertii, denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 268.

The hoard comprised 152 coins of which 128 were studied by Dancoisne. There were 12 sestertii and 116 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), although Dancoisne does not specify which coins are which! The hoard was found by workmen by the side of the river: -116 coins; silver weight: 34.0-336.1g.

A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have one fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's contents.
12 denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
99 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: 11 provincial bronze coins minted in Hadrianopolis found in the dirt when digging a sewer: Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 618, 624, 628, 632, 635, 639, 642, 645, 648, 654, 657, 684, 694

summary: The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 4,000 sestertii from Augustus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Some of the coins were in the possession of colonel de Tourville (in 1846)

summary: 191 silver coins: 132 denarii, 57 antoniniani (radiates), 2 imitations of antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Around 1,000 antoniniani found with a ceramic jug: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

A hoard of 24 provincial coins (ranging from Antoninus Pius to Geta) and 5 antoniniani (Gallienus) were found in a small pocket behind the stage of the theatre in Corinth, at the level of the marble pavement.
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 66 g to 270.3g.
A hoard of 387 antoniniani of Probus found during the excavations of the Roman fort of Vemania.

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver weight: c. 28.0-124.0 g.
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).
8 kg of silver coins. 1406 were kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria, until 1971 when 662 coins were stolen: denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 933

summary: (Circa 86) 14 aurei: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282)? Found together with 2 gold bracelets, 2 gold earrings, 1 Gold chain.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (10 aurei)

summary: (36) 34 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip (AD 244-249).

A hoard of 907 coins, found in a broken clay pot during building work carried out with a bulldozer: one Parthian drachm (Orodes I), 771 didrachms and 4 drachms of Caesarea in Cappadocia up to Geta, and 131 Roman denarii up to Alexander Severus, as well as one drachm of Caracalla attributed to Petra and dated to AD 211-12 (listed as a coin of Elagabalus from Caesarea by Dundua 2008).
Circa 30 silver coins were found with a ceramic vessel. 10 antoniniani (radiates) were identified: Gordian III - Valerian I (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).
Said to have been found at Satala. The hoard comprised 17 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Carus.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of small radiates (officials or imitations?), from Victorinus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.
45 denari: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

The hoard was found inside a coarse-ware vessel, of a blackish colour. The coins were within a compacted, ferruginous mass and comprised 47 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 259.
The hoard comprised 583 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 175.8g to 727.8g.
14 provincial bronze coins: 13 Tomis, 1 Marcianopolis (Moesia Inferior): Pertinax - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie Constanța, Romania; Inv. nos. 78427-78440

summary: 24 silver coins: 3 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Caracalla - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2372

summary: (5 or 6 kg. coins, c.1500 coins?) silver coins, 16 recovered: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 21.5-34.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2499; 16 coins

summary: Several reports mention several silver coins (probably a hoard) ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found on the Flürener Heide, on a sand hill, close to Diersfordt, Flüren. The coins have been dispersed.
16 bronze coins were bought by the museum: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. XXV

summary: 1 as, 1 sestertius, 1 denarius and 7555 radiates and a bronze ring to AD 274.

572 silver coins: 22 denarii, 550 antoniniani (radiates): M. Aurelius (Lucilla) - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 180.5-1484.6 g. Found together with Gold jewelry: 1 necklace, 2 rings, 2 sets of earrings
52 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 269). 1 Denarius.
Six billon coins of Alexandria found in a grave: Probus - Maximian I (AD 293).

ca. 1200 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with a bronze vessel, but only 390 are identified: 72 denarii, 318 antoniniani (radiates). Found by metal detecting The hoard contains coins from Pertinax to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. Two dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.

A hoard of 10 denarii (Septimius Severus - Alexander Severus) discovered during groundwork for the continuation of Harthauser Street into wooded area in southern Harlaching. The coins lay close to the remains of a skeleton.
Hoard of over 1,000 coins of the time of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
65 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257); silver weight: 82.6-167.6 g.
500 provincial bronze coins. N. Mouchmov saw 6 of them: Marcianopolis: Septimius Severus 2, Macrinus 1, Elagabalus 1, Severus Alexander 1; Nicopolis ad Istrum: Macrinus 1
The hoard comprised c. 200 antoniniani (radiates) (tpq AD 274).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4,000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.

The coins were found amongst fragments of ceramic building material (brick). As coins were very rare finds on this site, it is likely that they represent a small purse hoard or a portion of a larger deposit. 7 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 4.2-15.9g.
6 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 5 provincial: Hadrian - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 209-212 Found on a shipwreck
The hoard comprised 12 coins from Volusian to Salonina, found together in a single mass.
5,989 Roman denarii (Augustus - Septimius Severus, AD 209) and one drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Antoninus Pius) were uncovered, hidden under the floor of a house.
Four antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).

170 bronze coins: 83 official, 87 provincial of Alexandria (Domitian - Maximian I). During excavations in this region, where many Roman settlements are known, this lot was presented to de Looz by the mayor of Hannut.

7,426 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271); silver weight: 1783.8-13513.7 g.. It is not clear whether this hoard was part of the deposit found on the site in the nineteenth century, or whether it represents a separate hoard on the same site. The hoard was found during rescue excavations by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques des Pays de la Loire after an individual found coins scattered on the ground surface on several occasions on the site of a Gallo-Roman villa.
15 bronze coins: 8 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 6 asses: Gaius (Agrippa) – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
disposition: Regional Museum, Hradec Králové, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 2963-2977)

summary: The hoard comprised two coarseware ceramic vessels containing approximately 5,000 radiates from Gallienus, Claudius II and Aurelian, as well as issues of the Gallic Empire. 16 coins from the hoard recently reappeared and comprised issues of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Postumus and Victorinus.
369 bronze coins: 368 sestertii, 1 as: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-261).
10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.
216 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 215 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 242-244); silver weight: 303.1-491.4 g.
76 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 18.9-30.0g.
62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).
21 denarii and 28 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
12 silver coins: 1 denarius, 11 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 665 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 168.4-774.0 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (647 coins); Ilie Constantin private collection from Caracal, Romania (18 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 71 silver coins and 85 bronze coins from a Roman shipwreck.
68 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
It comprised 3,000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
The hoard comprised 75 tetradrachms (Nero-Trebonianus Gallus), found in the vicinity of Jerusalem.
disposition: Dispersed, Formerly owned by Dr. Schalit (Jerusalem)

summary: A hoard of about 80 antoniniani was discovered by treasure hunters in the late 2010s between the villages of Stanislavchyk and Bud’ky in Vinnytsia region. It is known that the hoard contained coins of Gordian III.
The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins from Gallienus to Postumus. Found during flint extraction.
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

During ancient excavations on a Roman iron production site, a hoard of 110 official and local imitation radiates was found. The coins ranged from issues of Valerian I to Tetricus I and II, with a single outlier of Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard comprises 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I with a tpq of AD 274.
7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
103 coins: 7 antoniniani, 96 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 17

summary: 55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver weight: 69.9-128.8 g.
126 sestertii: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
(58) 14 coins were donated: 7 republican denarii, 6 imperial denarii, 1 provincial bronze: Republic - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 76.6-205.9 g.

The hoard comprised an unknown quantity of coins. D. Guillony gave a portion of the hoard to the Musée de la Ville. It consisted of 31 very small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, which were for the most part unidentifiable with the exception of some coins of Tetricus. They are likely to be imitations. The hoard was found 'by chance'.

The hoard comprised more than 1,000 (?) coins, which were either bronzes or radiates. 72 coins were preserved in Auzances. The bronzes were extremely worn and sometimes illegible. 62 were sestertii and 7 dupondii or asses, although TAF does not assign denomination by emperor.
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus (AD 260-269).
8,400 denarii: Mark Anthony - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further information on Hoard?tructure.

Two antoniniani (radiates) of the brothers Macrianus II and Quietus, placed on either side of the head of the deceased, and a coin (pierced) of Caracalla minted at Paphos, placed over the chest. Burial cave.

A possible small hoard of 30 coins given to Alton Museum in 1953. An accompanying label stated that they were dug up "more than a century ago" at Hartley Mauditt. HER record states that they "include 9 of Claudius II, 20 of Gallienus and 1 of Valerian".
Unknown number of coins found with a vessel in a wall. The land owner had 9 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan Decius - Postumus.
The hoard (a purse?) comprised 8 coins of Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Quintillus.
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: The hoard comprised 2,676 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Quietus, Postumus, Laelian, Victorinus, Marius, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius Gothicus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian I.
2,382 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 644.1-2976.5 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (110 coins and fragments and casts); collection Meire, in 1950

summary: 18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Three coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only three antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.
IARCH record of a hoard of 11 sestertii from Devon. For details see DEV-37EC41.
12 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and ending ca. AD 255, found on the Zugerberg.
disposition: Amt für Denkmalpflege und Archäologie, Zug

summary: Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 26.6-117.8g.

104 silver coins from Mark Antony to Caracalla (AD 215): 103 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found spread in a debris layer in the southwest tower of the city wall. The layer was brought to level the floor after the AD 365 earthquake.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.

The hoard was found in a ceramic 'piggybank' and comprised 3 cistophorii from the mint of Asia and 402 denarii (including one ancient copy). Following x-ray and the use of endoscopy, the coins were removed through the slot in the moneybox by a conservator at Side Archaeology Museum, S. Okumuş Tek and technician Z. Avcu. The hoard was found in a deep trench in the north eastern carpark during the excavation of the Late Antique Baths

462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: 11 burned antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275). Two lots of 8 (24.09g) and 3 (8.83g) coins.
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 270 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Aurelian. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 73.9g and 336.5g
160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 292 denarii from Domitian to Maximinus (AD 238).

A hoard of 402 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus) was unearthed on a property in the Mangelhausen district of Wiesbach. The coins were originally contained together with a golden finger ring in an earthenware jug.
21 coins found hidden behind in a wall whole in a Roman villa: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 18 sestertii, 2 asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.
39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.
8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.
Uknown number of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 9 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Popovo: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
151 silver coins: 17 denarii, 134 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Trebonianus Gallus/Volusianus (AD 253).
disposition: The Iron Gates Region Museum Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (1957)

summary: 21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a) 1 or more aurei. Coutil states that there were six. B) approximately 1,600 silver and billon coins, almost all being radiates. C) Three ogold pendants (?) 'coulants' were also recovered. The hoard was sold at auction in May 1880. According to Angérard, the State (the Cabinet des Médailles?) acquired the aureus of Faustina. The Musée d'Évreux has 63 coins from the assemblage and Louviers, 43 (including issues of Valerian, Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Claudius II). Gold: 6? (1) coins; Gold weight: 19.3; Silver: 2, 1343 coins; Silver weight: 365.8-3493.2

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about fifteen antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver weight: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. antoniniani recovered: 1 Gordian III, 3 Tranquilina (AD 238-241).
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: 259 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 257)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania Bucharest 1971 (194 coins); ing. Octavian Lucian (65 coins) in 1971

summary: Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: Four provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.
Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: 112.2-779.3 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 138 silver coins: 45 denarii, 93 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 181.2-323.9 g.; Septimius Severus -Philip I (AD 246-248).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (file 1951) (130 coins)

summary: 219 sestertii: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) found in a cooking pot covered with a bronze sheet.

The hoard comprised between 960 and 1012 denarii from Galba to Elagabalus. Only 413 denarii from the hoard were studied. Silver: c.1000 coins; Silver weight: 1411.7-3148.3 g. Found under some stones by a farmer
disposition: Musees de Beaux-Arts, Quimper acquired 350 coins and Brest (Sociéte Academique) acquired 41.

summary: Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.

The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in two by the finder. One part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of one known as Lusigny A.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 63 antoniniani (radiates ) are known: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
A possibly large number (1700?) of Roman coins were found at Cadnam, in the Forest, contained in a thumb pot. This included coins of Tetricus (I or II?).
4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in one (or two?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
30 provincial bronze coins minted in the 3rd century AD found by metal detecting within the area of an ancient settlement.
The hoard comprised '20 denarii [actually, antoniniani (radiates)] of Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian (?), Gallienus and Postumus.
43 silver coins: 42 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 39 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Herod Philip (4 BC - AD 34) and Gordian III (AD 238-244).
361 antoniniani/radiate: Gallienus - Tetrachy (AD 292-293)
The hoard was enclosed or set within a square-cut stone and comprised 11 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Postumus (including E.384 and E.385).
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised 21 sestertii and 2 dupondii or asses from Trajan to Severus Alexander. It was found on an ancient floor surface in the corner of a room during archaeological excavations.

The coins were lifted en masse and when treated in the conservation lab at the BM some were found to be fused together in rolls with remains of cloth and string preserved in the corrosion products; good physical evidence that they were buried together in antiquity.
1,400-1500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 479 coins were available for study: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Carnac (in 1893, 460 coins); Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80315, 18 coins)

summary: 68 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 184-293); silver weight: 11.4-20.1g.
500 coins of which only 16 were seen have been found on the canabae area: Tiberius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Circa two kilos of coins and jewelry (2 bronze bracelets). For years it has been considered that Janapole and Dargeliszkie were two separate hoards. 14 bronze coins are hosted in the Museum "Alka" in Telšiai: Severus Alexander - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).

50 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II were found in association with the jaw bone of a skeleton in a lead coffin, suggesting that they had been placed inside the mouth of the corpse. The coins were characterised be being excessively thin and were therefore thought to be minimi.
Five antoniniani (radiates): Valentinian I and Gallienus - Postumus. Unknown circumstances of discovery.
800 silver coins: 503 denarii, 297 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247). Near the hoard was discovered a votive inscription.
disposition: Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania; inv. no. I 3555

summary: Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.

At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'. The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.
(circa 15 kg) 1926 antoniniani: Valerian I - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXI

summary: Large hoard of denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Uncertain composition due to the complex story about the real number of hoards found in this area and how the finders split the finds. Denarii from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 202). Based on the catalog from TIR M 34, pp. 157-180, it contained 3,170 silver coins: 3,169 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla (Augustus)) (AD 202).
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.
19 denarii found by metal detecting: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard was found when a farmer noticed coins in a molehill. The villagers then excavated the area and found a stone vault from which two copper-alloy vessels were recovered, along with between 25,000 and 30,000 silver and billon coins which had placed in a pile close by. One vessel contained jewellery and some gold coins. The second vessel contained approximately 620 denarii. Fillon noted that coins of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus represented 9/10ths of the the assemblage. The latest coins of Postumus date to Elmer's 14th issue. The discovery attracted attention and soon other villagers discovered two bronze vessels and the vault in which they had been stored. The hoard was dispersed amongst numerous private collections in 1856. These included Arthur Parenteau de la Voute (250 reverse varieties), O. de Rochebrune, Hanaël Jousseaume, De La Brière, Charvet etc. 23 examples were give to the Sociétè Industrielle d'Angers, 18 to the Sociétè des Antiquaires de l'Ouest. Fragments of the 2 copper-alloy vessels were acquired by the Musée de la Roche-sur-Yon and some coins, including the sestertius of Julia Domna. The Musée archéologique de Nantes acquired 4 spoons, 18 finger rings, 2 earrings, 2 bracelets and 414 coins, of which 212 were of Postumus.
298 provincial bronze coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement: Commodus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria, inv.no. 3634 (262 coins - 218 were stolen)

summary: Hoard of 281 antoniniani (radiates) found on the territory of the legionary fort: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns

summary: 539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
The hoard comprised 9 bronze coins dated to the reign of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 31 Roman Provincial coins from Nicopolis from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus, found south of Nicopolis, at Agios Phaneromenes Vathi (Αγιας Φανερωμενης Βαθυ), where one of the three harbours of the city was located. The coins were found in two lots (of 5 and 26 coins), recovered at a few days interval, and both hidden under a tile.
226 silver coins were found at a spot somewhere between school and a mound: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2259-2286

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 sestertii 'of 25 emperors, caesars and empresses' from Vespasian to Gordian III, mostly in a corroded or worn condition. There was also a single unworn bronze of Postumus
The original total number of coins in the hoard is not known, although 14 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Two provincial coins, minted in Alexandria (Diocletian and Maximian), found on a field in ca. 1900.
(700) 160 silver coins: Trajan - Valerian I/ Gallienus (AD 253-268). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring.
During archaeological excavations, 11 burned bronze coins were found on the south-east corner of the basilica: 1 Rome, 10 provincial: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 1 radiate of Claudius II and 38 Provincial coins of the early third century AD, found in a grave (Grave Θ) in Amphipolis in 1976
122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

A hoard of 16 antoniniani (Julia Domna - Gallienus), found in the shop II of the Stoa of Attalos, on the agora of Athens. The tpq for the hoard is given by the archaeological context, which corresponds to the the sack of Athens by the Heruls.

Found in a gravel pit while digging for gravel, along with potsherds. Located in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Of approximately 1,500 coins, ca. 1,270 are preserved in the Liestal Museum and 756 are issues of the Gallic Empire (Postumus, Victorinus, Tetrici). The coins seem to have been arranged in rolls inside the vessel.
The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.
17 coins: 1 denarius, 16 provincial bronzes: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2491

summary: In a ceramic vessel were found antoniniani from Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). 1,153 coins are kept in the History Museum in Lom. 886 antoniniani belong to Volusian.
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; inv.no. 2470 (1153 coins)

summary: (100) 12 denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3426-3437; local school in Suhindol (10 antoniniani of Trajan Decius)

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel filled with 15 Roman silver coins and 600 small bronzes of the same module (radiates). The reverse of one coin is given as MARTI PACIFERO, A/-. It appears to be an issue of Gallienus (RIC V/1 236?)
497 bronze coins: 496 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia (252 coins)

summary: One aureus of Tacitus, one gold barbarous imitation of an aureus, 4 drachms Hadrian, 1 denarius Septimius Severus were found in a grave together with jewelry.

The Wiggensbach hoard was discovered in 1889 in Waldegg. The hoard consists of jewellery, the quantity and typology of which is not described by FMRD, and silver coins, mostly denarii and at least 4 antoniniani, with coins ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander. 384 of them were bought by the Heimatmuseum in Kempten. 25 remained in a private collection. A list of them exists, but it gives only the name of the emperor. FMRD speaks of 407 denarii, but lists only 401 coins among which a few antoniniani.
disposition: Allgäuer Heimatmuseum, Kempten, 25 specimens in private collections.

summary: 20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information
Unknown originally number of coins. 30 aurei: Nero - Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Augustus) (AD 202).
1,587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
60 large bronze coins (i.e. sestertii) were found in a bowl in Trier, in the suburb St. Barbara inside Roman stonework.
The hoard comprised 2 radiates and 17 Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa and Koinon of Macedonia), found in Koufalia.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 1,500 antoniniani (radiates), including issues of Postumus.
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1,219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver weight: c.812.3-7797.7g.
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD
27 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 34.3-69.1 g
The hoard comprised 4 coins of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) and 2 unidentified coins.
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: In the vicus was found a hoard of 161 sestertii: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 267).
1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.
20 Alexandrian bronzes found in ceramic vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Cleopatra VII - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

(+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: 25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).
(c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: 108 kg found in a large ceramic jar and, probably, a box or, rather, of a canvas bag or leather, according to the rectangular shape of the second heap of coins: 41,200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Among issuers Valerian I, Gallienus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Claudius II, Postumus, Laelianus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II. Notably Gallienus and Claudius II (27%), the Gallo-Roman emperors Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II in particular (56%), and local imitations. A rare denarius of Tetricus I.

The hoard was found hidden in the hollow base of a statue and comprised coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Probus and Tacitus. The nummus of Constantine I/Gratian, probably, a intruder.
5 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Valerianus I (AD 253-260).
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver weight: 203.3-1735.5g.

Unknown Initial number of coins. 1509 silver coins: 1,486 denarii, 6 plated denarii, 17 antoniniani (radiates) Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 244). Silver weight: 4,710 g. Around 30 coins are still missing
disposition: Muzeul Regiunii Porților de Fier, Drobeta-Turnu Severin (1,502 coins); Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova (7 coins), Romania

summary: The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
487 silver coins: 227 denarii, 260 antoniniani (radiates): Balbinus - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
1,937 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Musées Royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: 32 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
Hoard of aurei and jewelry: 94 aurei: Nero - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold weight: 648.8g.

The hoard comprised at least 30 sestertii, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Claudius II with a tpq of AD 268 to 270. The coins were discovered as an oxidised lump and were found in close proximity to a silver finger intaglio ring with chalchedon setting.
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, five of the nine coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised a jug containing an agglomeration of 1,454 Roman coins found with a small ceramic vessel. Gallia states that 1,458 coins were found, but only 1,454 were detailed. TAF suggests that a further 4 unidentified coins could be added: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: c.248.3-1144.0g.
7 denarii undescribed (Vespasian - Severus Alexander) found in fortifications.
The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
On the basis of their condition and inventory numbers the coins perhaps also belong to the complex of the Keplerstraße hoard, see CHRE ID 3713.
Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
The hoard comprises of 67 silver coins, 34 denarii, 33 antoniniani (radiates), from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a tpq of AD 249-251.
(195) 180 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 245.1-503.7 g.
76 silver coins: 54 denarii, 22 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found during landscaping and construction work at the Tennis Club, Cherchell.
317 silver coins: 2 denarii, 315 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
168 denarii and Antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
28 sestertii: 15 Severus Alexander, 13 Gordian III found in the Dominican convent area.

The hoard comprised 606 radiates from Balbinus to Postumus with a tpq of approximately AD 263. The hoard contains official issues up until Postumus' Issue 1c (AD 261) but there are two radiates which copy coins of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 141.2 and 1222.6g.
81 provincial bronze coins discovered in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17 096-17 176

summary: The hoard comprised 49 sestertii from Trajan to Philip I and 2 Provincial bronzes from Patras (Caracalla).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 9 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I

An aureus of Trebonianus Gallus and a gold barbarous imitation of a Roman coin were bought in 1855 by the Coin Cabinet of the Museum in Berlin from a local from Jelenia Góra. No certainity whether the coins were actually found in this town.
disposition: Sammlung des Münzkabinetts in Berlin (17551-[1] coin und 17552-[2] Barbarous imitation. Unknown nowadays location.

summary: A hoard of 42 denarii, 294 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 provincial coins, found during excavation at the 'podium temple' in Alexandria Troas. Coins range from Septimius Severus to AD 260.
(100) 32 coins, 1 aureus, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; 29 coins; inv.no. LVII; History Museum, Lovech; 2 coins; inv.no. 1784 1-2

summary: "A thousand coins hoard coins found with a ceramic pot". 874 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: Fund 'Il Castello", inventory list; the hoard was probably sold on market

summary: 1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.

In 1864 reportedly more than 300 Roman coins were dug out at a field behind the Zorn'schen machine factory (on Landshuter street between Richard-Wagner street and Stobäusplatz). Descriptions of only 56 coins (1 denarius and 55 antoniniani, ranging from Julia Domna to Numerian) exist today. The coin of Numerian might not belong to this hoard.
4,000-4,500 antoniniani found in a cooking pot. 1501 pieces are presented here combining the evidences of Brunšmid from the year 1880 and the FMRSl I: Gallienus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia (few coins); Kunsthistorischen Museums, Wien, Austria (coins of Claudius II); Collection Markl (coins of Tacitus); Collection Kolb. (coins of Florian); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed

summary: The hoard was found in a cut stone vessel and comprised more than 1,800 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Gallienus and Carinus.
It is unclear whether this is a complete hoard or belongs to other coin finds (not recorded).
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver weight: 40.1g
The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 radiates of 'the epoque of Postumus and some contemporary official and ursurper emperors.'
Around thirty antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.
(Circa 20) 17 silver coins: Elagabalus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1832 1-17

summary: The hoard comprised about 4,000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be two hoards.
The hoard is described as being 32 small bronze coins (radiates?). There are 20 coins of Gallienus and 12 of Claudius II.
395 silver coins: 280 antoniniani, 115 denarii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
Unknown initial number of coins. only 6 silver coins are known: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 7.5 g.
A hoard of 276 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in room 2 of B. 8, east of the Agora.

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: 698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 190.0-1811.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (10 coins of Postumus); collection De Bove (34 coins), in 1882

summary: 136 silver coins: 74 denarii, 62 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 38.3-350.5 g.
disposition: Collection E. De Breyen (67 coins), in 1881; Town museum, Ieper, Belgium (vanished in 1914)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing numerous antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Gallienus, Claudius II and Tetricus I.
10 provincial bronze coins. 1 of Septimius Severus, 1 of Caracalla, minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with two golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Originally were 500 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 120 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Clodius Albinus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Until AD 253, Mints represented: Rome, except 2 from Laodicea for Septimius Severus and Geta; 2 from Antioch for Elagabalus and Philip I; 2 from Viminiacum for Treboninanus Gallus and 2 from Milan for 'les divi'; after AD 253: 1 Rome, 9 Cologne, 1 Viminiacum, 1 Milan, 1 2nd eastern Mint and 1 uncertain. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 698.4-1425.8g

The hoard comprised 113 Roman silver coins of different sizes, bearing the portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Aemilian, Valerian I and Gallienus. Apparently, this list is not exhaustive. The hoard is probably one of antoniniani (radiates), although perhaps some denarii were present.
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 17 pieces are in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 16324-16340

summary: Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).
Hoard of 12-15 kilos of coins - 5,500 pieces - found with a ceramic vessel. Only 270 were recovered: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Cludius II (AD 268-270).
992 coins: 14 denarii, 900 antoniniani, 1 sestertius: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 259); and jewelry of precious metal
158 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 5 kg of silver coins with issuers from Nero to Severus Alexander. Only 1,350 were recovered, among which: 233 Septimius Severus, 71 Caracalla, 5 Elagabalus, 5 Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1764.3-3938.9 g.

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).
287 Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) found under a slab: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
(700-800) denarii and antoniniani. 251 coins are kept in the museum in Isperih: Galba - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
382 coins. 332 coins in the museum in Vidin: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 438-463 (today, less than 300 coins)

summary: A hoard of 11 coins (denarii and bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to Alexander Severus) was found in 1965 in a walled Roman stone cellar, west of the Jewish cemetery. It lay concealed without a container under the threshold to the cellar.

Within lumps, the coins were arranged in stacks shifted sideways, 389 silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates). All coins were covered with a light green patina. There are 88 denarii: Clodius Albius to Gordian III and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Macrinus Valerian I and Gallienus).
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
1 kilo of antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins, 20 were issues of Claudius II (AD 268-270).
7 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (284-293).
108 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 265-266); silver weight: 26.4-195.3 g.
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A Roman coin hoard was found in the field of a sexton containing more than 100 silver and copper coins, with most of the silver coins made of bad alloy. The sources mention coins of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Gallienus, Salonina, Aurelian and Probus. Four coins are listed in FMRD, of which a description exists. It can be assumed that the hoard comprised mostly antoniniani of the middle of the third century AD and was buried between 276 and 284 A.D.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the monetary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4,000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3,000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in two piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.
100 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13604/1-100 (100 coins)

summary: 60 silver and bronze coins found by workers 19 provincial bronze coins were aquired by the Varna Archaeological Society: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
116 sestertii: 106 Viminacium, 10 Provincia Dacia: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253)
disposition: Museum of Sremska Mitrovica, Serbia (117 coins) - 1966

summary: A hoard of 265 provincial bronze coins (of which 202 were identifiable), found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 15, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).). Many of the coins were badly preserved. 63 illegible coins were are not listed in Bellinger's Final report.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I described as being small in size and therefore likely to be barbarous.

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy bucket or situla and comprised 76 sestertii, 4 dupondii or asses and 1 radiate from the Flavian period to Gordian III and 65 bronzes of Postumus. These included 7 doubles sestertii from the mint of Cologne, 17 'large bronzes' from an uncertain mint, 23 'middle bronzes' of which many were cast and 18 bronzes of a size and weight which would suggest that they were imitations.
Hoard of circa 350 coins. 285 were seen: 284 antoniniani (radiates), 1 aureus: Claudius II - Diocletian (AD 284-294); gold weight: 5.34g; Silver: 284 coins; silver weight: 51.2-90.8 g.
2043 AR: Galba/Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 2555.4-6392.7 g

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1,100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only two pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.

The hoard comprised 2 silver coins and 39 bronze coins. They were identified by Moreau de la Ronde who noted that they were all coins from the reign of Gallienus. The silver coins obviously date to before AD 260.
186 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Severus Alexander, found compacted together during building work on the Augustusplatz. A few coins were lost.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy jug containing more than 1,800 coins, mostly of Diocletian and Maximian. According to Derriaz, there were a few issues from the mint of Rome, with the remainder being mint of Lyon issues. The jug was acquired by the Musée de la Civilisation gallo-romaine, Lyon (Inv. Br. 208)
810 silver coins: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 1014.2-2363.7 g.

Approximately 10,000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,400 denarii with the latest coin being of Severus Alexander (or according to Blanchet, Gordian III).
The hoard comprised 12 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Salonina, Saloninus and Postumus.
7 coins: Nerva – Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
disposition: Regional museum, Kolín, Czech Republic (6 coins)

summary: c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
The hoard comprised 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian II with a tpq of AD 258. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 65g.
8 coins: 6 antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Postumus (AD 260-269).
112 coins: imperial and provincial: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver weight: 217.0-343.5g.
Hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 7,206 coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269). The largest number of coins belonging to Gordian III
54 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla) (AD 249-25); silver weight: 68.1-139.3 g.
disposition: History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. II-1768

summary: A mixed hoard of circa 250 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) dating from Septimus Severus to Valerian I (AD 253-259).
The hoard was found in a wall. It comprised c. 400 bronze coins from Nero to Gordian III (AD 238-244). This hoard was divided in two lots.
disposition: H. Ponroy Collection; Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland

summary: It is not certain whether there were one or two hoards. The hoard(s) seems to have comprised between 100,000 and 380,000 coins: Mark Antony - Maximinus I Thrax. Two hoards were found in a short period of time, 40 m from one another in January 1936 in March 1936.
disposition: National Museum, Niš (3,941); National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (3,123); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia (4,096); National Museum, Ljubljana, Slovenia (c. 830); National Museum, Prague, Czechia (15,000); Šipuš collection (64 coins);

summary: The hoard comprised a bronze statuette and approximately 300 silver coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus. The coins were bought by the Abbot Carlier, curate of Bavay. The statuette was acquired by the Museum of Douai where it remained until 1944 when it was destroyed in a fire.
An unknown quantity of coins was found in the outskirts of an ancient settlement. 31 silver coins were examined: 13 antoniniani, 18 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2579

summary: On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during maintenance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique stone floor.

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 334 coins were extracted from a hole sunk in the earth below two large stones, placed as it seemed, purposely above it. The coins were of Gallienus, Probus, Tacitus, and Claudius Gothicus.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 10 known: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 58.2-107.9 g.
(200) 27 silver coins: 6 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 251.3-514 g.
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: A large hoard of c. 22,500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22,500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.
Originally 44 coins, 41 pieces recovered: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Between 296 and 334 coins. The coins came out following the blasting activities on the Lueg Canal. G. Dembski considers as hoard these coins due to homogenous aspect of this numismatic evidence: Vesasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
211 silver coins: 106 denarii, 105 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Private collection Dr. Coriolan Bucur, Bucharest, Romania

summary: About 20 antoniniani (radiates) found during prospections. Only 10 of them were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus or Gallienus (sole reign) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
(c. 900) 11 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found with a moneybox: Titus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
(c. 300) 49 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight of 63.8 - 128.7 g.
The hoard comprised c. 700 coins including 200 sestertii and 500 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Claudius II.
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver weight: 57.8-100.7g
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 3 denarii and 610 radiates from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1756.6 and 16896.9 g.
67 silver coins: 63 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Direction des antiquités historiques, Paris, France

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 9 silver coins: 7 denarii, 2 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 33521-33529

summary: Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.

Hoard of radiates from the excavations at Angel Yard, Colchester. The exact number is uncertain - the existence of a scattered hoard was assumed from the profile of coin loss at the site. The coins were distributed in an accumulation of topsoil dating from the third century to the medieval period. A group of 9 denarii to AD 222, a group of silvered radiates and a group of barbarous radiates are all thought to have come from this hoard accoding to Crummy and Crummy (1990, 4) but it is perhaps more likely that more than one hoard was present within this group.
Unknown initial number of coins. 2788 antoniniani: Philip I - Gallienus (AD 260-268)
disposition: National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (2,639 coins); inv.no. 233-697, 730, 731; National Museum, Niš (149 coins), inv.no. 1668-1786

summary: 11 provincial bronze coins found in the barracks: Severus Alexander issued at the mints of Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis (AD 222-235).
A hoard of 40 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB, VB/C, VC and VI), found among brocken crockery on the floor of the kitchen of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.
43 silver and bronze coins, plated denarii: 41 denarii (19 plated), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). Found in the Principia building of the 5th Macedonica Legion fort.
The total number of coins found is not known although it is suggested to be as 5,000 pieces. Only 251 coins kept in a local collection were studied. Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Circa 400 coins of which 87 were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Tetrarchy(AD 299).

Over 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) (8 kg) found with a amphora-like vessel. The largest number of coins belongs to Postumus. Other issuers: Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina. An Alexander is mentioned among issuers, Severus Alexander (?).
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 7.9-46.6 g.
76 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates), 25 sestertii; silver weight: 16.5-147.8 g.

The hoard was found in a well under the Roman ramparts and comprised 18 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins were from the mint of Rome, with the exception of a denarius of Severus Alexander from Antioch and two denarius copies of Caracalla and Severus Alexander.

44 Antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 44. Together with coin was found a male bronze statuette of 75 cm height. Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120193: 1-27; A 8173). 17 coins were lost during the period of the WWII

summary: 43 silver coins: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 61.6-125.1 g.
The hoard comprised a vessel 'filled with 500 3rd century coins which were immediately dispersed.' Workmen tracing the route from Neufchâtel to Gamaches.

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD (see Robertson nos. 649 and 888). 67 coins, ranging from Valerian I to Allectus, placed in a cist dug in the earth together with animal bones, pieces of coarse pottery, and a blue bead, nearly the size of a walnut.
(746) 668 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253)

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 5,000 bronze coins. They were bought by M. Molchnet who stated that they included coins of Postumus, Victorinus, and a very large number of coins of Tetricus I. The hoard was found by a farmer, leveling of the ground surface in a barn.
200 coins were discovered. Among them coins of Philip I.
100 provincial bronze coins found in a bronze vessel. 39 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12089 (39 coins)

summary: The hoard was found whilst dredging the marshland close to the railroad from Saint-Omer to Calais. Silver: 1636 (1450) antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 442.7-2044.0 g.

The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.
Three bronze coins: 2 sestertii of Hadrian, 1 double sestertius of Postumus (AD 264-265) found in a layer of ashes in a cellar of a Roman building.
(250) 180 silver coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 314.1-710.9g.
disposition: Museum of Slavonia Osijek, Croatia (250 coins) - 1981

summary: A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
Unknown originally number of coins. 156 pieces are known of which 39 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius.
Hoard of 25 coins of the Bosporan kings: Cotys III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,600 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263.
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).
(c. 1400) 1352 antoniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: c.1751.4-3638.7 g.
disposition: Museum Dauphinoise, Grenoble, France; part of the coins and the container.

summary: The hoard comprises 102 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Museu de la Porciúncula, Palma, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1,100 and 1,500 silver and bronze coins, weighing 2.5kg. Desjobert who saw a small number of the coins, detailed that the coins included issues of Caracalla, Plautilla, Severus Alexander to Claudius II. When the hoard was dispersed, Drouet bought 27 radiates for the Musée du Mans including 7 Gallienus, 4 Claudius II, 4 Postumus, 3 Victorinus The hoard was found by a worker cleaning a fountain.

Over 1,054 coins were found, most of them oxidized together. Only 120 have been recorded to the level of the coin. Some 12 coins may have been lost (loose from the bulk of the hoard). Silver: 1054 (1, 127) coins; Silver weight: 285.7-2505.4g.

22 aurei, mostly fragmented and some of them holed: Gordian III - Trajan decius (AD 251); gold weight: 33.97g. The hoard contained fragments of 22 aurei. The total number of fragments amounted to 28 pieces. From these fragments a whole coin, ¾ of a coin and half of a coin could be reconstructed. The rest of the fragments contained the individual parts of the remaining aurei. All coins were in very good condition, with shiny, not worn surface. The fragments of nine coins had holes. Ann iron sword and a gold jewelry were found together with the coins. In the area of a burial ground from the Wielbark Culture, among the graves. Under a layer of dark humus appeared in the bright sand four recesses of 5cm diameter in a semicircle with a diameter of about 50 cm (rests of rings). Each recess contained a larger amount of gold coins cut into quarters.
315 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 297 denarii, 18 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 439.5-814.6 g.
A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
39 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-256). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: 284 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
155 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 216.6-451.6 g.
523 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver weight: 1143.8-2361.7g

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwritten note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.

A hoard of Syrian tetradrachms (668 according to Coin Hoards, 666 according to Bland) ranging in date from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus. It is said to have been found at Iskenderun, 57 km north of Antioch.
A purse of 14 provincial coins from Athens (period VB, VC and VI), found on the floor of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
4 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Provinciaal Utrechts Genootschap van Kunsten en Wetenschappen, Utrecht, Netherlands

summary: The hoard comprised somewhere between 2,000 and 2,500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).
27 silver coins discovered while ploughing: 14 denarii, 13 antoniniani: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2093-2118

summary: The hoard comprised 24 antoniniani: Gallienus (sole)-Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270 AD).
disposition: Museo Civico Bottacin di Padova, Italy (inv.nos. 24174-24196)

summary: A hoard of 243 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, including 5 Eastern coins of Septimius to Geta and one uncertain of Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkey (inv.no. 1861)

summary: The hoard was found in a vessel and comprised approximately 2,000 antoniniani (radiates), with the majority being Gallienus, Postumus and 'some other Gallic emperors' 'The hoard was found on the ground surface during flint extraction in the triage du Parc, around 2 km from the village in the Breteuil forest.' There appears to be an error with this findspot description as the triage du Parc is 8 km from Breteuil and is in the village of Bémécourt.
