A. Marsden writes:Group of 14 copper alloy radiates of Carausius (7) and Allectus (7). Condition is generally poor (due to corrosion not wear) but the coins were retrieved from a small area and clearly form part of a dispersed hoardAs mentioned, most of the coins are corroded but it can be seen that their condition when they went into the ground was evidently very good. Given this lack of wear it is very tempting to connect the deposition of this coin hoard (assuming we are not dealing with an accidental purse loss) with the reconquest of Britain by Constantius Chlorus in 296. Certainly, given the demonetisation of these radiates in 296, the hoard cannot date to very much later.
651 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from M. Antony to Philip I, found in a Roman cellar south-west of the Roman fort.

The hoard comprised 'an earthenware vessel filled with 652 silver and billon coins (denarii and radiates) and 100 bronzes (sestertii and dupondii or asses). The silver and billon coins weighed 3.7kg. A further 186 coins were offered for sale in Rouen in 1971 and appear to be from the same hoard.' The coins were deposited at the Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen, where 168 examples were actually conserved and catalogued by Mme J. Delaporte. Archives Inventory No. 2-653.
disposition: Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen (Archives Inventory No. 2-653)

summary: HER record of a second scattered hoard of radiates of Tetricus I and II from within site LKH 003 found c. 1978. No further information, many thought to be unreported.
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: (+500) provincial bronze coins. 37 pieces entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard was found scattered on the ground surface amongst the remains of a building and comprised 100 Roman bronze coins from Trajan to Severus Alexander. The coins were mostly worn sestertii.
The hoard comprised 9 antoniniani (radiates). The emperors represented include Gordian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salonina. There is no catalogue.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: The hoard was found within the temple temenos in Insula 20 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 390 denarii and radiates from Marcus Aurelius to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269, as well as a gold finger ring, two silver finger rings, a pair of gold earrings, a silver bowl, three silver spoons, some silver fragments and a copper-alloy vessel. A silver denarius of Hadrian was set into one of the silver finger rings.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 100 'base silver denarii' [probably radiates]. The majority of the coins date to the period of Gordian and the Philips. According to TAF, it is possible that the closing date for the hoard is much later - Valerian I or Postumus?
Circa 780 broze coins, 778 studied: 776 imperial bronzes, 1 dupondius/as, 1 provincial coin (koinon of Cyprus): Vespasian to Philip I.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 sestertii from Trajan to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). 92 were acquired by the City Museum of Nevers.
4,370 coins found in a cooking pot with graffiti (ME X): 4 denarii, 4,366 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: Centre archéologique de la Mayenne, Jublains, France

summary: 350 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only coin of Julia Maesa is known.
191 coins, range: Hadrianus -Trebonianus Gallus. Almost all of them sestertii, some halved.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing at least 313 antoniniani (radiates) radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 51.2-99.8 g.
disposition: Regional History Meseum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1410-1414

summary: 38 imitation antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I found under the granite foundations of a central building from the fort.
11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold weight: 7.1-7.2 g; silver weight: 17.2-22.6 g.
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 coins were documented: Vespasian - Elagabalus (Julia Soaemias) (AD 218-222).
Unpublished hoard of three denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).

A hoard of Roman bronze coins, next to a few gold ones, found during the construction of the railrepair workshop in Neustadt. It was acquired by the museum in three successive lots (A-C: 26 coins, 5 coins, 1 coin).
6 aurei: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 255-256). The hoard comprises also gold and silver jewelry and tableware. Gold weight aurei: 32.8-41.1 g; silver weight: 645.2 g
disposition: Museum of the Romano-Gallic civilisation, Lyon; Museé des Beaux-Arts, Lyon

summary: 108 antoniniani (radiates)Ș Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).

Around 1910 a hoard with 423 Antoniniani was salvaged during excavation of a building pit. The find spot ('auf den Kästrich') could not be further circumscribed, so that it is uncertain whether the deposit was found inside or outside of the legionary camp. The find is said to have been found with leather remnants in an earthenware container.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,000 3rd century antoniniani (radiates), including an example of Gordian I or II.
14 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 19

summary: The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Hoard of 17 silver coins, comprising 7 denarii (Elagabal to Maximinus) and 10 radiates (Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus)
A big vessel full of Roman imperial coins, bronzes and antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.
Bronze pitcher with 957 coins: 952 antoniniani (radiates), 1 double antoninianus, 4 denarii: Severus Alexander - Carinus (AD 283-285).

The hoard comprised approximately 600 silver coins (denarii and radiates). The antoniniani (radiates) were described as being of 'large and medium module' according to Bocquillet. There were 38 different types from Commodus to Postumus Found during embankment works for the Château-l'Abbaye road.
The hoard comprised a cut half-as of Trajan and 800 antoniniani (radiates), which were mostly imitations from Gallienus to Probus.

The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised an amphora containing approximately 5,400 Roman coins, weighing 143 kilos in total. They were mostly sestertii with some 'middle bronzes' (asses, according to Hollard 1992, 99). Blanchet catalogued a selection of 132 from the collections of the Musée Carnavalet from Gordian III to Postumus Silver: 1, 50 coins; silver weight: 17.4-63.0g.
disposition: Musée Carnavalet, Paris (132 coins); Sanatorium Nestor Pirotte Angicourt (120 coins, possible lost)

summary: The coins were found during the rescue excavation of a villa: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
34 bronze coins: 20 sestertii, 14 asses: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).
Unknown originally number of coins. According to I. Mira there are 2,842 coins known, all antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo del Seminario de Santiago, Braga, Portugal (68 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a huge number of Roman billon coins (radiates). It was noted that the composition of the hoard was almost identical to that found on Rue Beauvoisine (TAF IV. 61).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France (36 coins). Inv.no: II, p. 79, no. 845-6 (1853)

summary: A hoard of 260 provincial bronze coins (Domitian - Gallus, including one from the First Jewish Revolt), found at Dura Europos, in L8 W102, the street along the wall near the main Gate.
294 bronze coins: 292 sestertii, 2 small bronzes, found with the fittings of a wooden box: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).
2,236 silver coins: 415 denarii, 1,821 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
72 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) (AD 203); silver weight: 133.5-256.7g

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least two separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.
The hoard comprised a small red ceramic vessel with a lid containing approximately 150 coins of the second and third century AD. It was probably a hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates).
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.3-26.2 g.
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 53 bronze coins dated between AD 69 and AD 247-249.
2,596 denarii (among: 1 plated, 47 'barbarous'): Republic - Caracalla (AD 214).

Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2,377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).
1,204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1,199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: Twenty copper Roman coins from a salt spring: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 7.3 to 19.6 g.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.
51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins. However, only 268 coins were catalogued: . The rest were sold: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian /Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Instituto Arqueologia de la Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal (200 coins); Mário de Castro Hipólito collection (68 coins)

summary: 63 coins: 9 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Found in the baths.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 743-782

summary: A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 150 sestertii and dupondii, asses or antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard was found in a stone conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.
On the site of the Roman theatre, a hoard of 24 sestertii wrapped in cloth was found .
The hoard comprised 39 sestertii from Vespasian to Julia Domna, 4 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 7 radiates from Gordian III to Otacilia Severa with a tpq of AD 248 to 249.
1,200 imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268).
170 Roman imperial large bronze coins: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268). Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928b.

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction stones, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.
Group of 2 coins found with an urn: Maximinus I Thrax bronze, Gordian III antoninianus (radiate) (AD 238-244).
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).

15 coins in a pot, found on Podington Wold in the early 19th century, including coins of Gallienus (AD 253-268) and Philippus Augustus (AD 244-249), a stone described as of circular form with a hole for a winch, which sounds like a rotary quern, and fragments of pottery.
Hoard of circa 2,000 coins. Only 129 pieces were recovered they were all issues of the Bosporan kings: Sauromatess II, Rhescuporis II and Cotys III (AD 228-234).
disposition: Former military museum of Kuban (129 coins).

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 74 denarii (232g) were analysed by the Archaeological Commission: Vespasian Septimius Severus. Four coins were described in detail.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg (1891), Russia; Podillya Antiquities Museum, Kamyanets-Podilsky, Ukraine (4 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised two black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20,000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
Unknown originally number of coins. Seven coins are known: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 3.1-7.8 gr.
1233 silver coins: 2 denarii, 1231 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 258).

A farmer from Buprich uncovered an earthenware container filled with many Roman coins in the vicinity of the village. The container appears to have contained more than 1000 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus). 832 of them were described, but giving only the reverse legend, not the type. 727 are listed in FMRD.

(1200) 290 denarii: Otho - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). Found together with: 1 gold torque of twisted wire, 2 silver torques, 2 silver bracelets, 10 silver appliques, 1 silver brooch, 1 silver ring with inscription.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXXXIX (1934)

summary: 415 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 413 antoniniani (radiates), 1 possible bronze coin, 1 possible denarius: Trebonianus Gallus/Volusian - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).
14 uncertain denominations: Republic - Philip I (AD 244-249).
53 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 223).

The hoard comprised 'a large number of coins of various rulers'. It is likely to be the same hoard as one found 'close to Saint Pol' comprising 200 coins mentioned in a letter from the antiquarian Beaucousin to Mionnet
4-5 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 2 coins are known: Gordian III, Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar).
The hoard comprised approximately 200 silver coins, only for 97 of them were known the issuers: Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (AD 235-238).

In a small Roman urn found in the bank of a pit at Wishaw (which adjoins Wig-ings-hill and Cat's Hill) were several Roman coins - seven Gallienus, two Victorinus, five Tetricus six Claudius and several uncertain.

A hoard of 387 silver coins, including a large quantity of posthumous Philip Philadelphus (121, year 19 to 32, i.e. 31-18 BC), Roman denarii (141, up to AD 207), Syrian tetradrachms (29), Arabian didrachms (Trajan, 3 coins), as well as Parthian drachms (92 up to Artabanus IV, 213-227). The later coins of Severus and the members of his family are in mint state. Found in the Nineveh excavations in the 1929-30 season.
disposition: British Museum (154 coins); the Birmingham City Art Gallery (17 coins); Sir Charles Hyde (25 coins); Bagdad museum (196)

summary: 60 denarii and antoniniani found in a small ceramic vessel. 10 coins: 5 denarii, 5 antoniniani kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; 10 coins, inv.nos. M ??? 5107-5116

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.
Circa 1,000 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelian; silver weight: c. 271.0-1249.0g.
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).

More than 200 Roman silver and bronze coins were found in 1880, in the barn of the house no. 20 in Ronsberg. 61 were identified in the Munich state coin collection and 6 are listed in FMRD; the imperial series ended with Severus Alexander.
Silver: (c.3500) 1100 silver coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c.4377.3-12562.7 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (3 coins); Collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (147 coins)

summary: Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,401 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

142 coins in two vessels containing 71 sestertii from Titus to Septimius Severus and 71 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus. Only 54 were recovered and studied: 30 sestertii, 24 antoniniani (radiates).

80 bronze coins were bought by M. Alexandrov: 1 sestertius, 79 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum 38, Marcianopolis 30, Hadranopolis 4, Anchialus 2, Deultum 2, Augusta Traiana 1, Pautalia 1, Nicomedia 1.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 927-991

summary: 7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

summary: 43 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 206-210). Found together jewels and dices embedded in a wall.
23 coins: 22 denarii, 1 as (Augustus - Caracalla/Elagabalus) (AD 210-222). The last coin is a hybrid Caracalla/Elagabalus.

The hoard contains 37 silver coins (18 denarii and 19 antoniniani-radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259). This hoard has been discovered along with some single coins from the Celts and Romans (sestertii from Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus).

Scattered hoard, found in the Dünnern river bed during correction works of the river bed. Over 1100 coins reported, 906 of them preserved. 8 coins from the 1st/2nd c. AD, the others range from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Postumus to Tetricus II. Mostly antoniniani, except for the 1st/2nd c. coins and a denarius of Gordian III. Large numbers of coins from Gallienus and Claudius II.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1,500 and 1,800 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 sestertii of Divus Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander and Postumus.

The hoard comprises 182 antoniniani (radiates). The 182 pieces were found stacked on three rows: in the first two there were series of 13 to 15 coins forming tubes on the edges above the lowest series. At the lower level they appeared more arbitrarily placed in a larger radius. Three tegulae formed a vault over the whole.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
A suspicious hoard as there is very confusing information whether there is a hoard or more hoards put together following the excavations in the area of a Romano-Visigothic necropolis:
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 29 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised 10.6kg of coins. Mints represented are Rome (3195); Milan (135); Viminiacium (1); Siscia (151), Sirmium (2), Antioch (1); Cyzicus (10); Cologne (13); Trier (11); uncertain (53) Found during the construction of a vault. Silver: 28, 3590, 47 coins; Silver weight: 1008.5-4527.4
1,576 coins found in two ceramic vessels: 1 denarius, 1,575 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea), Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c. 300.6-2,110.7 g.

A hoard of 15 coins, found in a grave (grave 4) during the excavations at Pylos, in Volimidia, north of Chora. It has been described as 13 sestertii and 2 antoniniani, though Vlachogianni and Tourastoglou give a slightly different account of the emperors represented (see under References).

559 denarii - 1,607.31 g found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). ToOn the same field were found a rectangular bronze pendants and one of gold and a brooch. Uncertain whether these artefacts are connected to the hoard.

The hoard comprised 1,016 coins (1,015 antoniniani-radiates and 1 denarius). The hoard was discovered by two workmen on a building site, less than 50 metres from the Gallo-Roman baths, in an earthenware pot that got broken. The Hôtel de Ville d'Allonnes has preserved 386 coins from the hoard.
114 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus I (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. inv.no.741-758, 760-766,768-770,772-780, 782-842, 845-855, 982

summary: Seven imitations of silver denominations; silver weight: 151.4-695.3 g.
The hoard comprised c. 1,500 coins from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
163 kilos of bronze coins (7,000-7,400 coins) discovered at the beginning of the 19th century. Only 200 coins are known: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and two drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: 933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).
700-750 bronze coins. 483 provide some information and 273 can be entered at the coin data level: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
180 bronze coins: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Six silver coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring and a bracelet: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
600 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Found close to the hoard ETTELBRÜCK 1889. Silver: 592 coins; Silver weight: 161.1-740.3g.
The hoard was found in a hollow stone and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

18 silver coins: 4 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Claudius II (AD 268-270). Together were found jewelry: 2 silver bracelets, 1 gold pendant, 3 gold rings, 1 gold earring and fragments of silver earrings.
disposition: Museo di Antichità di Torino, Italy

summary: Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani. 11 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Commodus 1, Severus Alexander 1, Gordian III 6, Philip I 2, Gallienus 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13715-13725 (11 coins)

summary: 102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins: 10 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Commodus - Philip I (244-249 AD).

The hoard comprised 15 coins including one 2nd c. sestertius, one denarius, 11 radiates and two Provincial coin from Athens from Period VI (AD 264-267), found under burnt debris on the floor of a room of a large Roman house on the lower slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel. Preliminary study suggests that 10% are of Gallienus, 60% Postumus and some coins of Tetricus I and II.
79 denarii and antoniniani were found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
25 denarii found on the east wing of the north facing gate: Galba - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 214).

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The money consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Two pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
This hoard of twenty three coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
A hoard of 13+ Roman coins (Caracalla - Gallienus), found after 1850 during house construction in Cottbus.
11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-246).
517 bronze and electrum Bosporan coins: Rhescuporis II - Ininthimeus (AD 238).
27 coins. 26 denarii. One possible barbarian imitation: Septimus Severus- Severus Alexander (ca. AD 235.)
67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
While ploughing, a ceramic vessel with 13 antoniniani of Aurelian was found.

The hoard was found near Keldenich, on the Tanzberg in an earthenware urn that was shattered by the workers who found it. It comprised 10 pound (or 20?) of Roman silver coins. The coins (4000 according to Haupt) were dispersed and only the names of some of the emperors represented were recorded (Vespasian - Severus Alexander).
The hoard comprised 1 denarii and 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Victorinus. The coins were stuck together with corrosion products.

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.
A doubtful hoard of 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) found by amateur archaeologists. Not confirmed by the "official research".
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii: Domitian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222 ). Only 42 coins are now available.
Three aurei of Gallienus (AD 260-268). Two of the coins are soldered. Traces of fire
313 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Caracalla (Geta) (AD 211-212). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: 212 coins were preserved. They comprise radiates, Reform radiates of Aurelian and 3 denarii of Severina
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised more than 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) of which 1,038 were acquired by the Musée des Antiquités de Rouen' 'Une pelleteuse heurta' hit the vessel in which the hoard was buried: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 281.2-1296.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
Unknown number of silver coins. 19 antoniniani are known: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2729

summary: 42 silver coins: 2 denarii, 40 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised two Roman Imperial coins of Severus Alexander, found in grave 6 of the east cemetery in Thessaloniki.

The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.
108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
15 coins: 3 denarii, 5 antoniniani. 7 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 10.9-17.1 g.
241 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 67.4-624.3 g.

1043 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 285-286). The emperors represented include: Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Divus Claudius II, 'Imp. Gallo', Aurelian and Probus. However, the original number of coins was ca. 3.840.
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Spain

summary: The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised twelve antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.

IARCH record for a fused lump of denarii, of which three could be identified as issues of Severus Alexander, The others (3 and a fragment) could not be identified due to the condition of the coins. Possibly burnt as they are deformed into a fused mass (total wt. = 14.01g).For further details and images see YORYM-6C737B
The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).

This hoard comprised 522 coins: 7 denarii, 515 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-263). Beside were discovered: 7 gold rings, 6 silver rings, 1 silvered bronze ring, 1 gold earring and 1 bronze earring.
The hoard comprised 2394 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses Galba to Gordian III (AD 238-239).
The hoard comprised 4000 coins with emperors from Severus Alexander to Postumus represented. The hoard was found by a farmworker.
48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Large number of denarii and antoniniani. Only 27 pieces were identified: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat stone. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some bones. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat stone in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of one coin each in gold, silver and bronze.
(+2000) 1478 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 361.1-2499.1 g+
645 denarii, 1 gold necklace and other artefacts. 154 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: 29 antoniniani, 125 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. IX

summary: 495 silver coins: 1 denarius, 488 antoniniani (radiates): Augustus, Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 135.3-612.6 g.
596 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); Silver weight: 745.6-1548.5 g.
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9091-9632; 9469-9588 (557 coins)

summary: 391 silver coins: 287 denarii from Vespasian to Gordian III; 101 antoniniani from Gordian III to Philip I; 3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 1 provincial, 1 unidentified (AD 244-249); silver weight: 437.2-913.2 g.
775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
Unknown number of silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel. N. Moushmov examined 119 pieces: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard of 343 barbaric antoninianii (Gallienus - Carus, incl. Tetricus) and an unstruck flan were found in the substructure of a bathhouse of a villa rustica (HA 206).

Hoard of 651 coins found in several ceramic vessels and a textile cloth. 570 coins were studied: 16 denarii, 96 antoniniani (radiates), 458 bronzes: Galba - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: 134.0-1792.9g. One of the Postumus double sestertius is overstruck on a Marcus Aurelius sestertius of the type VICTORIAE AVG S C.

The hoard was found in a tomb and comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 75 (or 78) radiates, 17 surgical implements and 5 tinned or silvered containers, which probably originally contained ointment: Victorinus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 801 sestertii from Vespasian or Titus to Maximinus I Thrax with a tpq of AD 236. Although no trace of a container was recovered, the coins were found stacked, as if they had been stored in rolls in a box.

The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the nineteenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.
376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: The hoard comprised 1 Hellenistic coin of Thessalonica, 1 plated denarius of Septimius Severus and 28 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella and Stobi, Augustus - Gordian III). It was brought from Macedonia by a soldier who had found them while digging trenches.
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel with a lid containing between 1,800 and 2,000 radiates. No further information about the composition of the hoard was given.
17,533 antoniniani (59 kg) found in a bronze vessel: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus) (AD 249-251)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 932

summary: 38 coins: 9 antoniniani and 29 provincial bronzes found within the ruins of an ancient building: Macrinus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 11 silver coins in the Museum of Ruse: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 16.2 g.

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.

The context of the treasure burying, although partly known, remains problematic : in fact, there are two deposits of precious objects, very close to each other but quite distinct, inside caches which were laid under the ground. Should they be attributed to the occupants of the houses from the second half of the 3rd century AD, or to the occupants of the potter's workshop following in the beginning of the 4th century AD? The first deposit gathers together two silver bracelets and a group of statuettes in the same metal, more or less fragmentary. Three of them are fully preserved : one Helios dedicated to an emperor's numen, one Fortuna with a double horn of plenty and one goddess, more enigmatic, carrying a dish with two birds inside. The head of a Jupiter and of an amazing personage with two outgrowths as an ornament in the hair add to the whole which is completed by a bust-portrait, probably representing an emperor (Gallienus?). The second deposit, locked inside a wooden box, consists of crookery, jewels and coins. The silverware is made up of one dish decorated with a Mercure, two small trays ornated with reliefs (one of them just in bronze and silver plated), fourteen spoons and two fragmentary cutleries. All these objects belong to well known series in Gaul : their shapes and decoration show that they were made in the 3rd century AD. The set of jewels includes two golden bracelets, two pairs of golden, emerald, pearl and molten glass pendant earrings, two bezel rings (one of them with a nicolo), and one coin medallion (Gordian III aureus, AD 238-244). At the bottom of the box, there was a purse with 81 well preserved silver coins - 29 denarii and 52 antoniniani (radiates) - with a chronological curve stretching from Vitellius (AD 69) to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallian (AD 253-260). In fact, there are two different sets : one with 62 coins, that is to say 19 "old" denarii from Vitellius to Commodus, eight more recent all dated AD 201, 33 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius struck between AD 215 and AD 217 for Caracalla, as well as, one denarius of Diadumenian in AD 218; the second set comprises 19 antoniniani (radiates) coins issued between AD 241 and AD 258. One can wonder about the precise nature of these deposits. The sculptures found there do not have quite a homogeneous construction ; maybe a kind of Lares altar or objects belonging to a sanctuary, as most of them represent divinities, and one at least, the birds’ goddess, seems to have a strong local connotation. The silverware hardly represents more than two pounds of metal ; it is therefore difficult to speak of a "table set" all the less as the spoons are rather incomplete. The set of jewels, which is more coherent and of good quality but with no exceptional piece, illustrates well the favourite jewels in the well-off classes of Gaul around the middle of the 3rd century AD. Regarding the coins, there are several arguments speaking for a saving, rather than for a reserve currency, which was formerly made (maybe following two main payments (donativa) in AD 202 and AD 217/218, and poorly completed by a contribution in antoniniani (radiates) around AD 258-260), a small family inheritance safeguarded for sentimental reasons, maybe one generation away. (Aubin, G. et al. 1999)

The hoard comprised more than 35,000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape Fteni Punta. 149 Roman provincial silver and bronze coins found with a bag during archaeological excavations: 10 silver coins (4 didrachms, 6 drachms) of Caesarea in Cappadocia, ranging from Hadrian to Septimius Severus; 139 bronze provincial coins of Trapezus, ranging from Commodus (?, or Septimius Severus?) to Philip I (certainly AD 244/5, as this is the last time Trapezus produces coins). Authors disagree on the identification of the coins of Trapezus. These are badly preserved and were never published in detail. The list given here follows Kropotkin, as given in Depeyrot's translation. Golenko has a slightly different breakdown, including the mention of 4 coins of Clodius Albinus, allegedly from Trapezus. Kapanadze and Golenko also list 7 coins of Commodus, though these were grouped with Septimius Severus as uncertain by Kropotkin. The list provided in Tsotelia / Depeyrot 2010 does not offer further clarifications.
The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2,000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
Four gold coins found in a female grave: Septimius Severus 2, Philip I and Valerian I (AD 253-260).
8 silver coins: 2 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).
34 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 33 silver coins, 1 provincial bronze: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260).
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 7.1-9.3 g.

A hoard of 39 antoniniani (Gordian III and Philip I) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the middle of November 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on November 14, 2017. There is no additional information about the conditions of hoard find. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
81 coins of different denominations (sestertius, dupondius, as, and 1 denarius): Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
The hoard comprised approximately 70 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Forty-four coins are catalogued.

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
12 antoniniani (radiates) found close to each other: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).
10 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 2630-269); Silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.

'The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel filled with approximately 40 gold, silver and bronze coins with portraits of Trajan, Claudius II and Probus. The composition of this hoard is thought to be suspect.' The hoard was found in a small valley on the Guillet property.
Part of a larger hoard. 50 silver coins: 13 denarii, 37 antoniniani: Domitian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 64.6-130.2 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3173-3186

summary: The hoard comprised 372 coins that were fused together in a single lump. They comprised 1 denarius and 371 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus. The mint distribution is given in TAF (Rome: 210; Cologne: 93; Trier: 24) but not related to issues of particular emperors. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 100g to 111.0g.
26 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXVI

summary: Unknown quantity of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzik: Julia Paula, Gordian III, Otacilia severa; silver weight: 8.1-13.5 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 441-445

summary: Found by a fisherman amongst rocks off the coast of Ambleteuse. Silver: ? (137) coins; Silver weight: ? (24.8-43.8g)
disposition: Boulogne (statue, cup, spoons); The British Museum (ewer)

summary: A hoard found in 1979 to the north west of Bath and thought to be complete except for six coins. Very little is known about the discovery of the hoard, except that it was associated with a few fragments of lead which may be derived from a container. 1'807 of the coins were cleaned and catalogued prior to the resale and dispersal of the hoard; 1805 antoniniani, 1 denarius and 1 quinarius, ranging from Gallienus to Allectus.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a fifteenth century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver weight: 31.5-140.3g.
337 antoniniani, "almost all of them bearing the portraits of Claudius II and Tetricus I" (AD 271-274).
52 denarii, 51 antoniniani (radiates), 1 quinarius: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
Circa 100 silver coins. Y. Youroukova have seen 30: 10 denarii, 20 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 1 denarius Maximinus I Thrax, 3 antoniniani : 1 Caracalla, 2 Gordian III.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2591

summary: A farm laborer found a Roman coin hoard in a plot of a field in Lochhausen, 10 cm below the surface. The hoard contained approx. 1700 antonianini, of which 1675 specimens could be recorded. Part of the hoard was housed in the coin collection at Munich, but lost during the years of war. The list given in FMRD is based on the publication of hoard by M. Bernhardt in 1911. Unfortunately, this publication contains many mistakes and it is not any more possible to give an exact description of the content.
3 coins: Marcus Aurelius: denarius, dupondius; Trajan Decius sestertius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprises 127 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a top of AD 250-251.
339 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan Decius - Carinus (AD 284-285); silver weight: 62.1-422.8g.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt, Austria (64 coisn); various private collections

summary: It comprised 500 Roman silver and billon coins, of which only 104 were identified dating from the reign of Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius through to Carinus. It is possible that the radiate of Magnia Urbica is an intruder. Besançon mentions a coin of Maximinus Daia, but is an error resulting from confusion with Maximinus of Thrace. The hoard was found few meters from the hoard SAINT-GEORGES-DE-RENEINS 1880.

Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of four Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."
9 bronze coins, date, grave: Gaius - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard comprised originally ca. 2,400 coins (2,384 coins were mentioned in 1960), of which a small proportion has been lost. The coins were found in a copper-alloy vessel. 2 denarii and 2,302 radiates (incl. 7 imitations) ranging from Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian have now been published. Tpq is AD 293.
The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.
Unknown number of silver coins. 236 are in the Museum collection in Ruse: 230 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Republic - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria;inv. no. 1661

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani. 10 pieces were seen: Philip I, Otacilia, Trajan Decius.
It had been discovered in two earthen vessels. It comprised of 137 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 97 are now recorded: Pertinax - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

A scatter of coins from the hoard were found by a farmer. A systematic investigation of the findspot by Mr. Pioger and Térouanne recoverd a further scatter of 800 coins as well as excavating 3 vessels containing 3,600 coins (radiates and copies): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282). A catalogue of 1,941 coins was prepared by R. Boissel. In addition, there were 2,500 imitations and minimi. The coins were dispersed in June 1976, although some of the imitations were preserved in particular collections. A small portion of the hoard was found by a farmer. Following its discovery, there was a systematic investigation of the site. Silver: c.3600 (1941) coins; Silver weight: c.271.1-1874.1g
26 coins: 24 sestertii, 2 denarii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235); silver weight: 4.75 g.
disposition: Collection Ms. Ausselet, Charleroi, Belgium (26 coins and the lid)

summary: A hoard of 104 Roman coins (Philip I - Probus), found opposite the station of Mehrhoog, on a sand hill. The coins are lost.
Unknown originally number of coins. 31 pieces: 2 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Gallienus-Postumus (AD 260-269).
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins. 29 coins are kept in the Joanneum, Graz. According to G. Dembski the coins may rank from Severus Alexander to Gallienus.

The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: 17 provincial bronze coins of Caracalla found in a ceramic vessel: Serdica 13, Deultum 2, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1.
(200) 162 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: c.251.5-548.5 g. Found together with two bronze bracelets.
2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)
8 denarii found stuck together within a necropolis: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO C)
summary: Hoard in grave, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
Over 137 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 136 denarii, 1 drachm: Republic – Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (24 coins); Local Museum, Târpești (44 coins)

summary: 30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: The hoard was found in two vessels and comprised 6,700 Provincial bronzes chiefly of Samos, ending with coins of Gallienus (sole reign). Other mints represented include Naxos, Ephesus, Magnesia ad Maeander and Smyrna. The two vessels were resting against the wall of a house, built west of the 'Cicero-Exedra'.
disposition: Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Münzkabinett; Samos, archaeological museum

summary: 273 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised 2,186 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and 'other emperors of the same century.'

Hoard of 223 coins: 6 aurei, 217 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 27.1-30.0g.; silver weight: 59.8-315.7g. Together was found a ring (metal not specified).

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of provincial coins (Samos, Pergamum, Smyrna, Clazomenae, Metropolis and Nysa; Gordian III - Gallienus), seen in commerce in Athens, coming from Samos. 16 coins are listed, but 21+ are mentioned in the heading.
The hoard comprised approximately 500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I and Postumus and three bronze coins: 1 Lucilla, 1 Maximinus I Thrax, 1 Postumus (sestertii?) (AD 260-269).
(c. 400) 156 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan Decius - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
20 antoniniani found in a small ceramic vessel. Some of the coins belong to Philip I.
84 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I nd Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 24.2-151.3 g.
1058 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
(c. 200 silver, 2 gold coins) 31 gold and silver coins: 1 aureus, 18 denarii and 19 antoniniani/radiates: Vespasian - Valerian and Gallienus I (AD 258); silver weight: 40.6-67g
disposition: the Prince of Schaumburg-Lippe collection; Town Museum Virovitica, Croatia (173 coins); dispersed; Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (archives)

summary: 18 coins : 13 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
45 silver coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 63.1-128.9 g.

Circa 500 silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver gilded bracelets and 3 silver rings. 50 antoniniani are kept in the History Museum in Lom: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; (50 coins, 1 bracelet, 3 rings)

summary: The hoard comprised 493 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Valerian and Gallienus.
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Roma, Italy

summary: A hoard of an unknown number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 5 coins are documented: Domitian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Philip I (AD ).
Group of 38 bronze coins: 28 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 7 asses: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised 9 gold coins: 1 multiple of 6 1/2 aurei, 8 aurei: Trajan (Plotina) - Florian (AD 276). Together were found jewelry: small gold male bust, three old bracelets, three gold armillae, rolled gold band, jet (or black glass paste) bracelet, black material bracelet, six small jet (or black glass paste) pieces, bronze pin.
Apparently more than 500 coins in this hoard.

A small hoard of 25 Roman aurei and their imitations. This hoard was never published, however, according to Berghaus it contained two genuine issues and 23 cast imitations of Roman aurei, which prototypes can be dated from Lucius Verus to Septimius Severus. More than a half of them show evidence that they were made of the same moulds.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 1,800 Roman coins, most of which were sold. Leblond catalogued 315 examples from Philip I to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of approximately 541g to 2249.0g

In 1946 during peat digging the find was discovered in a marsh, between St. Annen and Lunden. The find consisted of a wooden box (not preserved) containing a small silver vessel (destroyed) with 9 pearls, one sestertius of Antoninus Pius, rolls of 23 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Caracalla), and 2 small bronze rings.

A hoard of 71 Pamphylian bronze coins, mostly from Perge (64) and a few other cities, as well as one coin from Selge in Pisidia that ranges in date from Caracalla to Aurelian. These coins were purchased by John Mossop, which the ticket 'Perge hoard, Dec. 66'. It is unclear whether 'Perge' refers to the find spot, or to the fact that most coins came from that city.
1,100 or 1,000 coins found with a bronze vessel. and gold coins from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Ceramic vessel containing 610 Roman provincial bronze coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 235-238). Minted mostly in Tomis (today, Constanța, Romania). Other mint, identified so far, Deultum; At the bottom of container, iron carpentry tools: penknife, clamping clamp, ax/chisel, wood gripper, bolt.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie din Constanţa

summary: The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.
A hoard of uncertain size, of which only 7 coins are known from Postumus (Elmer 131, 314, 335, 565, 566, 593) to Victorinus (Elmer 683).
Originally there appear to have been 19 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, However, Mattingly only reported on 18.
140 bronze coins: 130 sestertii, 10 dupondii: Vespasian - Macrinus (AD 217-218).

In 1880 a hoard weighing 10 kilos was discovered. In 1883, other 500 silver coins were discovered in the same village. In 1971, 6 coins from one of the lots were available for study: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I/Trajan Decius (AD 244-251).
disposition: Museum of History, Reșița, Romania (6 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. Five coins are known: 1 Greek coin, 3 denarii, 2 plated denarii: 2nd c. BC - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205). It may be a votive offering as suggested by some scholars based on the findspot.
The hoard comprised 654 coins of which a total of 444 were recorded. These included 442 denarii from the Republic to Severus Alexander and 2 antoniniani of Caracalla and Elagabalus.

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2,821 coins and 11 illegible ones, including one AE of Seleucus III, one tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2,817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).
(c. 300) 22 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: c. 82.0-374.0 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (7 coins); collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (13 coins)

summary: 236 coins: 6 denarii, 224 antoniniani (radiates), 6 sestertii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Found together with jewellery: 1 gold ring, 1 glass ring, 1 bronze brooch.
2 denarii and 436 radiates (Septimius Severus to the Tetrici), two silver finger rings, and one small silver ingot found beneath a stone by workers widening a road between Amlwch and Bull Bay.
4 antoniniani: 3 Gallienus (sole), 1 Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised 252 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Quietus with a tpq of AD 260. It was found in two ceramic vessels.

The hoard comprised an urn containing 1,200 coins, mostly thought to be dupondii ('moyens bronzes'), but with some asses ('petits bronzes') and denarii. The coins range from issues of Vespasian to Severus Alexander.

Hoard was found at a brickworks called Les Caves du Roi, between the road from Paris to Calais and Estrées and on the route of the trainline towards Berck. Three sestertii were overstruck upon pieces of Antoninus Pius (1) and Marcus Aurelius (2). Together wuth These coins were found: a coin-die (!); a pickaxe (dolabra); a spearhead.
19 antoniniani found during archaeological excavations: Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus
445 silver coins probably buried directly in the soil: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallu (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 497 coins, including 2 denarii and 495 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-260).
Large hoard of 160 denarii found in Præstemosen ("the Priests Bog") in the town of Gudme, close to a pond. The hoard had been totally ploughed up.
The hoard comprised 1,500 Roman coins from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
The hoard comprised more than 1,500 Roman coins. The Museé de Boulogne bought 100 coins ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus.
4127 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 1261.0-5249.0 g
disposition: Musée d'Annecy, France; inv.no. 3477 (3828 coins); 400 coins dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
A hoard of 107 provincial bronze coins (of which 74 were identifiable), found in the Roman barracks at Dura Europos.
Found in a ceramic vessel, 120 coins: 66 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 147.7-320.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2442, 120 coins

summary: 4,128 coins found in two vessels: 3 denarii, 4,125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).

A hoard of originally more than 200 antoniniani of which 147 were split up between different museums and a private owner. 116 of these were published in detail by Laser in 1972 (114 of these could be documented de visu by M. Schlapke in 2015) and FMRD gives a full list of all 147 coins. Unfortunately, the FMRD list is faulty. The mistakes are difficult to correct, as the coins are not all accessible any more today. As a result, all coins ever documented have been listed here, with three FMRD entries having their quantity set to 'zero' (0), as no matching coin exists among the ones seen by M. Schlapke. Surviving coins range from Valerian to Postumus. No trace of a container could be seen.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens (96 coins); Sondershausen, Schlossmuseum (8 coins); Gotha, Stiftung Schloss Friedenstein, Münzkabinett (31 coins, which cannot be identified any more within the collection) and 12 coins in private hands

summary: 24 silver found in a ceramic vessel: 18 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 34.1-63.8 g.
Hoard of circa 200 coins. Only 17 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259).
The hoard comprised 'approximately 120 Roman bronzes, principally sestertii, of which many were very crudely manufactured 'trés frustes'.
32 silver and provincial bronze coins: 5 antoniniani, 12 denarii, 15 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 26.1-38 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIX

summary: 2,944 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
15 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 20

summary: The hoard comprised 15 sestertii of Faustina I to Valerian I.

The hoard comprised 180 Provincial bronzes from Nicopolis, found next to a small countryside road, at Phloriada-Valtos, Plakanida, at the border of Aetolia and Acarnania. The list given here follows Calomino.

The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
29 bronze coins: 27 setertii, 1 dupondius, 1 dupondius/as: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,968 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). 1,862 of these coins were identifiable (219 denarii and 1,643 antoniniani (radiates) and form the basis of a catalogue by Le Gentilhomme (1946). The current hoard catalogue outlined here needs checking against this original publication.
13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II part of a larger hoard?
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.
416 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gordian III - Carus (AD 282-283) found in the courtyard, having been stored in an amphora and placed in a bin, during excavations of a house.
1 denarius, 33 antoniniani (radiates), 16 sesterti, 16 antoniniani (radiates) fragments, 4 nummi: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of 15 aurei (Marcus Aurelius to Caracalla), to be associated with Caracalla’s campaign in Adiabene in AD 216 and found in an Arsacid period house, south of the Sin-Shamash temple (find location fC6V).
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 15 coins (2 denarii and 13 Provincial issues: Thessalonica, Amphipolis, Stobi, Cassandrea, Koinon of Macedonia), found in sarcophagus 1 in Ierissos.
A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on one of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
51 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274).
192 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Republic 1, Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-249).
3 coins: Vitellius sestertius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate) (AD 244-245).
A large hoard of silver coins was discovered by Bulgarian soldiers. 6 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Gordian III 5, Trajan Decius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2735

summary: The finders show to Abbe Moreau c. 6,700 antoniniani (radiates). The workers discovered the hoard in three vessels and shared the coins. V. Huguenot studied few coins of this hoard, from Antoninus Pius (probably Elagabalus) to Postumus (AD 260-269).
156 silver coins: 11 denarii, 145 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 55.0-394.8g.

A very large hoard of approximately 25 or 30,000 coins (Severus Alexander - Gallic Empire, probably Victorinus), found in Friedrich-Wilhelm-Strasse. The coins were dispersed. 907 of them are listed in FMRD, in six different lists according to the place where the coins are kept today: 1) 595 coins in the RLMT Trier (FMRD 3064,3) 2) 54 coins in the RLMT Trier, with mention 'probably from that hoard' (FMRD 3064,4) 3) 41 coins bought by the RLMT Trier in 1925 from a private collector (FMRD 3064,5) 4) 30 coins in the RGM Köln (FMRD 3064,6) 5) 1 coin in private coll. (FMRD 3064,7) 6) 186 coins bought by the archaeological Museum in Zagreb in 1906/7 (FMRD 3064,8)
disposition: RLMT Trier; RGM Köln; private collection Lückger, Germany; Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia

summary: Found in a pitcher, the coins were placed in a textile bag. 936 coins: 14 denarii, 922 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Institut national de recherches archéologiques préventives, Paris, France

summary: 1007 silver coins: 201 denarii, 806 antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together with a silver brooch.

3,044 coins: 3,029 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii, 1 provincial coin: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 274-275). "The bulk of the hoard was formed in 273; several pieces, if not intrusions, were added in 285." (Harl, 79, n. 11).
100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
(250) 121 denarii found within an ancient settlement: Republic - Gordian III (AD 238-244)

A hoard of 155 bronze coins (2 hellenistic coins, 34 Roman imperial coins including 2 denarii, 12 provincial coins, 107 provincial coins from Gerasa), found within a linen purse close to the podium of the temple of Zeus, in a layer of reused material dated from the early 3rd c. AD.
10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 3.7-11.5g.

In 1837 six silver coins and one copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The six silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.
230 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised 1,942 antoniniani (radiates). Three coins (Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus) were given to the perish care taker, four coins (Gallienus) to the collector who helped the finder, of which 1935 were studied by Bastien and Huvelin. Silver: 1869, 66 coins; Silver weight: 505.6-2335.3g.
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the thirty tyrants' (AD 260-274).
Three coins found on surface one next to the other (AD 260-274).
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: Group of 6 coins (silvered antonini) stuck together into 'a column', with a 7th found close by, found in topsoil just outside of apse of bath house in commander's praetorium/principia in Bowes Roman fort, excav. by Hartley & Frere in 1966-67. Latest coin an issue of Constantinus II of AD 332. Coins may have been originally wrapped in linen (in Shotter's coin report). Topsoil above a rubble layer containing pottery, wall plaster, iron nails & building stone, but no other topsoil finds mentioned.D. Shotter, The Roman coins. In Frere, S.S. and Fritts, R.L. 2009. Excavations at Bowes and Lease Rigg Roman Forts, pp.56 to 66. Yorkshire Archaeological Report No. 6, pp. 39.The radiate of Tetricus is given as RIC 100. The coin of Victorinus is listed as a copy. Shotter excludes the nummus from this group.
The hoard comprised 16 radiates from Aurelian to Probus, found on the Agora in Athens beneath the post-Herulian wall, lost during the construction of that wall.
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Around 600 silver coins, of which 432 were seen: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Silver: 3 denarii, 208 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Diocletian/Galerius (Caesar) (AD 293); silver weight: 43.8-497.0g.
disposition: Landesmuseum Niederösterreich, St. Pölten (in 1977 in Wien), Austria

summary: Four coins found on a terra sigillata dish as grave-goods with an inhumation on the Inner Relief Road site B, Colchester (St Johns Abbey). Found with a greyware jar.Further details of the grave in Crummy et al. 1993, 205ff record that this was a child's grave and also contained the cranium of a dog. The coins were in a leather pouch or purse and found stacked.
Unknown number of silver coins. 31 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.

A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated one) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large stones, animal bones, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and one of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
